• Prerequisite: CTAN 101
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Animation and Digital Arts
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Freshmen

CRS_DESC: Developing skills in design, composition, shape language, image-making, and visual thinking to create more sophisticated style frames and imagery for animation practice.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Animation and Digital Arts

CRS_DESC: An overview of the evolution of computer graphics in modern media.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Tools, skills and procedures used in animation production with a focus on professional execution of independent and collaborative productions. Prerequisite: CTAN 102. Open to sophomore animation majors only.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTAN 102
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Sophomore
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts

CRS_DESC: 3-D animation performance utilizing preset rigs and virtual characters. Emphasis on timing, gesture, and performance.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Animation and Digital Arts
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Sophomore

CRS_DESC: Emphasis on lateral thinking working across boundaries to find underlying principles in terms of ideation: the act of becoming an agent of ideas.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTAN 301
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts

CRS_DESC: b: Completion and exhibition of the short animated film to demonstrate understanding and further examination of the possibilities of animation time based graphic media. Open to senior animation majors only.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTAN 401a
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Senior
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts

CRS_DESC: Creating characters and environments for animation, live action, and video games.
Seminar featuring guest speakers from major animation studios to provide an overview of a feature animation pipeline from development to pre-production, production and post-production.
Introduction to the expanding field of visual effects; topics include integration for cinematic storytelling and the study of digital productions employing the latest visual effects.
Workshop exploring concept and structure of long and short form animated films through practical writing exercises.

Lecture and laboratory in computer animation: geometric modeling, motion specification, lighting, texture mapping, rendering, compositing, production techniques, systems for computer-synthesized animation using Maya software.
The fundamentals of lighting and rendering in real-time. Creating complex, compelling and dynamic scenes and manipulating them in real-time using Unreal Engine.
The basics of character design for animation: anatomy, poses, facial expressions, silhouettes, and anthropomorphism. Development of a portfolio.

Survey of contemporary concepts and approaches to production in the current state of film and video effects work. Digital and traditional methodologies will be covered, with a concentration on digital exercises illustrating modern techniques.
All aspects of digital effects animation, including particles, dynamics, and fluids. Creating water, fire, explosions, and destruction in film.
Advanced techniques for animating 3-D creature characters in games. An emphasis on unique non-human fantasy characters.
Individual research under faculty guidance.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Animation and Digital Arts

CRS_DESC: Introduction to software packages and practices exploring current animation techniques that leverage simulation systems. Artificial intelligence as a tool for animation.
Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema and/or television; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.
Focus on film grammar, perspective, and layout, staging and acting as it relates to storyboarding for animation.
A creative studio course in producing both a linear cinematic virtual reality short film and associated real-time immersive experience.
Overview of the global production, media and entertainment industries and fundamental business skills, with an emphasis on animation and the animation professional.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Animation and Digital Arts
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student

CRS_DESC: Fundamental principles of motion capture technology explored while working through a structured series of assignments based around performance, gesture and motion.
A creative 3-D motion graphics course focusing on animation technique, design and skills in Cinema 4-D.

A special projects course in which students produce a major work through weekly meetings with a master artist/animator. Topics must be approved prior to enrollment. Recommended preparation: Previous advanced animation production experience. Recommended preparation: Previous advanced animation production experience.

Individual exploration in the areas of contemporary technology, animation techniques or experimental film through internships, residencies or directed studies. Open only to Animation and Digital Arts master students.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Animation and Digital Arts
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student

CRS_DESC: Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Graded CR/NC.
Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

CRS_NAME: Visions of Diversity in the Cinematic Arts
CRS_DESC: Representations of marginalized groups in digital media, and how they have shaped conversations, altered public discourse and policy, and impacted the lives of underrepresented people.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts
  • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Gateway to majors and minors in cinematic arts. Technique, aesthetics, criticism, and social implications of cinema. Lectures accompanied by screenings of appropriate films.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Exploration of the economic, technological, aesthetic, and ideological characteristics of the televisual medium; study of historical development of television and video including analysis of key works; introduction to TV/Video theory and criticism.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_NAME: Race, Class, and Gender in American Film
CRS_DESC: Analyzes issues of race, class and gender in contemporary American culture as represented in the cinema.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Diversity: This course satisfies the university's diversity requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_NAME: History of the International Cinema II
CRS_DESC: The development of international cinema from World War II to the present. Lectures, screenings and discussions.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Studies in the global configurations of television industries and cultures, including new technologies and the textual and sociological analysis of global media events and programming.
Exercise in writing film and television criticism using new and classic films and television programs.

CRS_NAME: Studies in National and Regional Media
CRS_DESC: Detailed investigation of traditions, achievements, and trends of film and/or electronic media in a particular country or region.
An inquiry into the practice and patterns of censorship in cinema.
Detailed examination of film/television from the perspectives and insights of Cultural Studies; focus on the production and reception of cultural texts, practices, and communities.
Examines how gender and sexuality are figured in cinema and television with an emphasis on the development of feminist media theory.
Rigorous examination of film and/or television genres: history, aesthetics, cultural context, social significance, and critical methodologies.
Lectures and readings on creative problems in the motion picture industry; current films; interviews with visiting producers, directors, writers, performers.
Lectures and readings on creative problems in the television industry; study of current and historical trends, interviews with producers, directors, writers and performers.
Intensive study of the style of an auteur, studio, film or television making mode in terms of thematic and formal properties and their influences upon the art of film.
Influential ideas and theoretical approaches that have shaped the making and study of film. Students are encouraged to take this course in their junior year.

An examination of transmedia, or cross-platform, entertainment: commercial and grassroots texts, theoretical framework, historical context, and commercial projects. Developing transmedia strategies for existing media properties.

CRS_NAME: Advanced Cinema and Media Studies Seminar
CRS_DESC: Rotating topics involving detailed study of the historical, cultural and aesthetic analysis of film, television, and new media technologies.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration closed to the following class level(s): Freshmen

CRS_DESC: Historical survey of global cinema from its beginnings until 1945.

CRS_NAME: Survey History of the United States Sound Film
CRS_DESC: Survey history of the United States film from 1927 to the present, with emphasis upon film as art form, economic institution, technology, and cultural product.
A survey course exploring the historical, cultural, business, creative, and technological aspects of the new interactive media.
Introduction to central concepts, key theories and leading figures in cultural studies, particularly as they relate to issues of popular culture and visual media.
Aesthetic, historical and ideological issues in avant-garde film and video.

CRS_NAME: Seminar in Film and Television Genres
CRS_DESC: Advanced study of a selected genre of film and/or television its relationship to history, society, and culture, as well as to genre theory.
Detailed investigation and discussion of various aspects of television, including genre, textual analysis, production and distribution systems and audience studies.
Seminar in theoretical approaches to cultural studies; focus on interdisciplinary research of media and audiences, covering a range of methods and theoretical frameworks; concentration varies.
Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.
Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of Dissertation. Graded CR/NC.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTCS 794D
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student

CRS_DESC: Survey of game software development through quality assurance and in-depth analysis of the development cycle with a focus on bug testing systems, methodologies and QA Management.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the ITP department but may qualify for major credit in CTIN. To register, enroll in ITP 181.

CRS_DESC: Introduction to the field of themed entertainment and education design, covering its history, and, especially, current practice.
Covers core skills for creating in a digital game engine, the role of prototyping in the game development and the use of version control systems.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (CTIN 101 or ITP 165)
  • Concurrent enrollment: CTIN 290

CRS_DESC: Exploration of a variety of moving image aesthetics and methodologies in order to highlight how the language of cinema shapes contemporary digital and interactive media practices.
Hands-on creating experiences for students who want to work as crew on an advanced game project.
Workshop on the production of miniature golf holes, considering theming, experience, and build.
Introduction to the aesthetics, terminology and common trends of interface design for games. Topics include 2-D and 3-D spaces and user/camera perspectives.
Concepts and methods of usability assessment. The emphasis will be on understanding the issues surrounding game interfaces, and utilizing usability assessment methods.
An overview of tabletop roleplaying games and the design space around roleplaying.
Foundational aesthetic principles and creative technologies for game audio. Processing, mixing, and controlling sound for games for expressive effect.
Overview of current business models in games and interactive media, methods for pitching and getting products funded; copyright and intellectual property.
Examine two game products from concept to delivery; introduce students to each of the professional disciplines involved in making digital games. Recommended preparation: CTIN 488.
Rigorous examination of interactive entertainment: genres, history, aesthetics, cultural context, and social significance. Topics vary by semester.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: In this class we study video games, cultural theory, and other media as we ask questions about the persistence of dystopian narratives in print and visual culture.

CRS_NAME: Directing for Games and Interactive Media
CRS_DESC: An introduction to the skills of directorial perspective, scene breakdown, thematic intent, project planning, team building, communication, situational decision-making and response to change.
Leading industry techniques and networking fundamentals; designing an original social game.
Best practices and strategies for streaming. Students build a personality and audience through the course, receiving advice and feedback from emerging leaders in the field.
An introduction to making games. Students will explore the principles of game design through the entirely analog creation of card, board and tabletop games.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: A follow-up to the introductory game design class, this course will introduce more advanced concepts in game design and game theories, including ideation, digital prototyping and level design.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTIN 488
  • Note: Section 18363 must be taken with CTIN 484 section 18357, and section 18405 must be taken with CTIN 484 section 18406.

CRS_DESC: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
Students work in teams to polish and finalize a functional digital game suitable for distribution via the web and/or submission into independent games festivals.
Pitching, production planning, forming a company and seeking funding for your creative media idea. Duplicates credit in former CTIN 497ab.
Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema, television, and/or interactive media; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.

Overview of foundational concepts required for design, development and evaluation of interactive entertainment and transmedia-based interventions at the intersection of neuroscience, public health and medicine. Recommended preparation: Proficiency in conducting literature reviews; social media use; using interactive media and playing games. Open only to seniors and graduate students.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Senior, Senior (fifth year), Master Student, Professional Year 1, Doctoral Student, Graduate Visitor

CRS_NAME: Research Methods for Innovation, Engagement and Assessment
CRS_DESC: Planning, designing, and analyzing a research study for a digital media project. Production of a written report and presentation. Recommended preparation: CTIN-506, CTIN-541, and CTCS-505.
The development of interactive experiences with an emphasis on prototyping and development.
Rapid prototyping and forward iteration of thesis project ideas developed in CTIN 548.
Experimental studio course in application of technology to interactive experience. Open to Interactive Media MFA students only.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTIN 534
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Interactive Media

CRS_DESC: An advanced production workshop in which students design and prepare for the production of their advanced project. Open to Interactive Media MFA students only.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTIN 532
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Interactive Media

CRS_DESC: The fundamentals of 3-D real time game engines, scripting for interactivity, and building games with digital tools.
Research project leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
Students from many disciplines work in large teams to create an innovative, large-scale interactive media or game project. Recommended preparation: CTCS 505, CTIN 541.
Small student teams produce, playtest and polish high quality games and experiences in an intensive project based studio setting.
Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC. Open to M.F.A., Interactive Media majors only.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTIN 594a
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Interactive Media

CRS_DESC: Credit on acceptance of theis. Graded IP/CR/NC. Open to M.F.A., Interactive Media majors only.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTIN 594B
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Interactive Media

CRS_DESC: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of interactive media; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.
Introduces contemporary concepts of production, emphasizing the variety of contemporary media and significant related concepts. Projects created using laptops, phones and networks.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_NAME: Originating and Developing Ideas for Film
CRS_DESC: Exercises in observation, imaginative association, visualization, etc., that deepen the creative process, leading to ideas, stories, characters, and images for narrative, documentary, and experimental films.
Introduction to the interrelationship of visuals, sound, and editing in cinematic communication. Workshops in directing and producing. Individual and group projects.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts

CRS_NAME: Directing in Documentary, Fiction and New Media
CRS_DESC: Basic concepts of directing in new media, documentary and fictional narrative. Includes work with actors, documentary concepts, and creation of short new media projects.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production
  • Concurrent enrollment: CTPR 295

CRS_DESC: The aesthetics and tools of the major disciplines of cinematic arts: producing, cinematography, sound, and editing.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production
  • Concurrent enrollment: CTPR 294

CRS_DESC: Principles of visual and aural communication; idea development and realization using image, movement, pace, the spoken word and other sounds; small crew projects.
Use of high definition motion picture equipment to explore the fundamentals of shot design, movement and lighting. In class group projects.
Theory, techniques, and practices in picture editing; use of standard editing equipment; individual projects.

CRS_NAME: Creating the Motion Picture Sound Track
CRS_DESC: Techniques and aesthetics for recording production sound, editing dialogue, sound effects, music, Foley and preparing for the mix. For film, television, and other media.
Preparation of director's preproduction blockout; study of direction for live, tape, and film production, for both dramatic and informational television.
Basic procedures and techniques applicable to production of all types of films; demonstration by production of a short film from conception to completion.
Explores the nature of storytelling through sound, and the technical skills necessary to create vibrant and intriguing soundscapes for these stories to live in.
Workshop in how editing can shape storytelling, using content from a variety of media and in various styles. Modern non-linear equipment and techniques.
Lecture-laboratory in makeup relating it to mood of the story and emulsion of the camera stock.

CRS_NAME: Introduction to Special Effects in Cinema
CRS_DESC: Introductory workshop in the aesthetics and practices of special effects, embracing both the classical and contemporary modes.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: CTPR 423 requires a mandatory safety seminar. Contact the SCA Student Production Office at (213) 740-2895 for date and place.

CRS_DESC: Camera and lighting workshop in color cinematography, beginning with digital still photography and moving into 16mm and advanced digital cameras. In-class exercises.
Theory, discussion, and practical application of production planning during preproduction and production of a film.
To provide students with basic working knowledge of both the skills of the motion picture set and production operations through classroom lectures and hands-on experience.
Exploration of the various aspects of color grading and how it can enhance storytelling.
The tools and skills necessary to turn an idea into a documentary story, using sample reels, pitches, and writing to develop a professional proposal.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: CTPR 431 requires a mandatory safety seminar. Contact the SCA Student Production Office at (213) 740-2895 for date and place.

CRS_DESC: A comprehensive overview of the role of the producer. How projects are conceived, developed, packaged, financed and marketed.
Aesthetic and technical skills of production and post-production sound necessary to create a motion picture soundtrack.
Introduction to the software necessary to create previs, pitchvis, CG films and quick experiments to practice creativity without being on set.
Integrating visual and scenario design in the construction of worlds as containers for narrative in documentary, drama, fiction, fantasy, and immersive media.

Detailed view of the process of making media. Introducing fundamental thinking typical of each craft. Weekend crew experience and responsibilities. Prerequisite: CTPR 310. Open only to Cinematic Arts Film and Television Production majors.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTPR 310
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production

CRS_DESC: Intensive examination of skills and techniques necessary for successful performances in film and television. Practical application through in-class exercises and assigned projects.
Introduction to drafting, set design, set decoration and creating models for students with diverse abilities. Guest lectures, group discussions and hands-on workshop.

Analysis of the unique structures in the entertainment industry for organizing and managing creativity. Students research and chart pathways to leadership. Open only to juniors, seniors, and graduate students.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior, Senior (fifth year), Master Student
  • Note: Section 18562 Designed for Production students in directing, writing, or producing. Preparing for a freelance life, finding representation, building networks, pitching yourself and understanding the business side of a creative career. Restricted to SCA grad level; D-clearance for undergrad seniors possible.

CRS_DESC: Financing, budgeting, management as applied to films; problems of distribution, including merchandising, cataloging, evaluation, and film library management.

CRS_NAME: Managing Television Stations and Internet Media
CRS_DESC: Managing electronic media, including radio and television stations, broadcast and cable networks, and the internet.

CRS_NAME: Directing the Television Sketch Comedy Show
CRS_DESC: Concepts and skills in directing sketch comedy shows, using the techniques of live television. Hands-on experience on live weekly shows. Recommended preparation: CTPR 371, or CTPR 476, or CTPR 484, or CTPR 523, or CTPR 532.
Practical instruction in script breakdown, location surveys, traditional and computer-aided working drawings, model making, set decoration, construction and scenic departments.

CRS_NAME: Practicum in On-Screen Direction of Actors
CRS_DESC: Concentration on the basic skills in working with actors from a director's point of view.
A real world approach to spotting music for film: why film music exists and the many ways it is used in storytelling. For filmmakers as well as composers.
Pairs produce, direct, shoot, and edit a short documentary on a subject of their choice. Finished projects will be suitable for broadcast/festivals.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: CTPR 474 requires a mandatory safety seminar. Contact the SCA Student Production Office at (213) 740-2895 for date and place.

CRS_DESC: Directing comedy: casting, rehearsing, directing actors, scene analysis, staging, shooting, and editing, leading to the filming of a two-person comic scene
Concepts of directing for motion pictures, emphasizing the working relationship of actors and directors. Scenes will be staged in class and filmed for class presentation.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTPR 310
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production

CRS_DESC: Directing seven short projects ranging from short exercises to a scripted and polished final project. Focus will be upon development as a director.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTPR 478
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production

CRS_DESC: Translating traditional storytelling tools into short form comedy that stands out online. Writing, directing and producing creative projects designed for current online platforms.
Writing, budgeting, shooting, editing and directing a music video and commercial. Getting the job, dealing with the band, working with the record and advertising companies.
Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema and/or television; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.
Foundations for fruitful collaborative experiences via readings, presentations, in-class exercises and real-life challenges and advice from professionals.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: The Friday class session is for the Graduate Equity and Inclusion Lab, which will meet twice during the semester, on February 17 and March 10.

CRS_DESC: Exploring the relationship between story structure and visual structure, discussion of aesthetics and technical controls, in-class examples and screenings, photographic assignments.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (CTAN 547 or CTIN 534 or CTPR 504 or CTPR 507)

CRS_DESC: The effective communication of ideas through the language of cinema. Individual and small group exercises; introductions to producing, directing, editing, cinematography and sound.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts

CRS_DESC: Practicum in group production, emphasizing the collaborative process and the expressive use of sound and image.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTPR 507 and CTWR 505
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student

CRS_DESC: A comprehensive overview of the world of reality television; each student will develop and pitch an original reality-based program.
How to direct comedy or dramatic scenes, using multiple camera techniques. Students also serve as crew members, learning lighting, mixing, studio controls, and stage management.
A preproduction workshop for the research and planning of a documentary project to be executed in CTPR 547 or an advanced production workshop class. Prerequisite: CTPR 508.
Practical experience in staging dramatic narrative scenes, emphasizing directing actors, rehearsal techniques and camera blocking.
Practicum in more complex directing issues concentrating both on performance and exploration of shaping scenes visually through blocking of action and placement of camera.
Editorial construction of sequences to analyze the interrelationships of the various film elements, both visual and aural.
Close study through practical in class exercises of the technical and aesthetic principles of cinematography. Introduction to 16mm film and advanced digital cameras.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (CTPR 508 or CTAN 547)
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts

CRS_DESC: Definition, examination and practical experience in the role of the line producer as it relates to preproduction, production and post production.

Telling cinematic stories using visual effects and virtual backgrounds, environments, and characters. Hands-on exercises emphasizing directing. Prerequisite: CTAN 462. Recommended preparation: CTAN 555 or CTPR 532 or CTPR 537. Open only to Cinematic Arts students.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTAN 462
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts

CRS_DESC: An advanced production class in directing. Encounters with experienced directors; and individual student production of a short. Recommended preparation: CTPR 533.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTPR 532
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts

CRS_DESC: Study of the technical and aesthetic elements of sound design at the professional level. Intended for those contemplating a career in the field of audio. Prerequisite: CTPR 540 or CTPR 546 or CTPR 547.

CRS_NAME: Advanced Professional Editing Tools and Software

  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts

CRS_DESC: Defines and examines the role of the Executive/Feature Producer through the preproduction, production and post production phases. Prerequisites: CTPR-538 or one of the following in equivalent crew position: CTPR 486, CTPR 546, CTPR 547.

CRS_DESC: Developing, pitching and selling your feature motion picture and TV projects.

  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): School of Cinematic Arts

CRS_DESC: Takes projects from conception to sale, including development, production, post-production, and marketing. Students will develop original projects.

Individual experimental projects involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound. Qualifying courses: CTPR 532 (for directors); CTPR 558 (for producers). Graded IP/Letter.

  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production

• Prerequisite: CTPR 573
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production

CRS_DESC: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound specifically designed for students who want to work in pairs.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTPR 587A
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production

CRS_DESC: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound specifically designed for students who want to work in pairs.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTPR 587B
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production

CRS_DESC: Advanced group project involving the creative use of visuals (live action or animated) and sound specifically designed for students who want to work in pairs.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTPR 587C
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production

CRS_DESC: Detailed investigation of new or emerging aspects of cinema; special subjects offered by visiting faculty; experimental subjects.
Writing a feature-length screenplay based on treatment developed in CTWR 206a. Includes a first draft and a polish.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTWR 206a
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Writing for Screen and Television

CRS_DESC: Examination of the fundamental elements of a good story, and how to use those elements to develop new screenplay ideas. Recommended preparation: CTWR 106b.
The fundamentals of writing for dramatic episodic television. Writing scenes from popular television shows and examination of television story structure.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (CTWR 100 or CTWR 402 or CTWR 409 or CTWR 413)
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (CTWR 100 or CTWR 402 or CTWR 409 or CTWR 413)
  • Note: Sections 19353, 19362, 19364 are restricted to WST majors.

CRS_DESC: The fundamentals of writing for comedic episodic television. Writing scenes from popular comedy series and examination of half-hour television comedy story structure.
Development of an original narrative podcast. Emphasis on dramatic elements of auditory storytelling and character development.
Introduction to writing compelling scenes, creating authentic characters, three-act structure and feature film outlining.

CRS_NAME: Character Development and Storytelling for Games
CRS_DESC: An exploration of characters and story worlds as they relate to gaming with an emphasis on emotionally rich environments in interactive enetertainment. Recommended preparation: CTIN 488
In-depth analysis of the craft of writing prime-time episodic television. Examination of situation comedies and dramas through weekly screenings and lectures.
Preparation of scripts for short films: form, structure, planning. Open only to Cinematic Arts Film and Television Production majors.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production

CRS_DESC: Students study story structure and develop several story outlines, write a short script for possible production, a feature film outline and first act. Recommended preparation: CTWR-416. Open only to Cinematic Arts Film and Television Production majors.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTWR 413
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Cinematic Arts, Film and Television Production, Cinema-Television

CRS_DESC: Principles of the feature film; creating theme, character and structure that combine into a feature-length story treatment.
Creation of script with extensive workshopping of scenes in class leading to a first draft and revision as a final assignment.
Critical analysis of story structure from classic films to contemporary works. Identification of key story concepts and elements of three-act structure. 2.0, not repeatable.

b: Completion and revision of Senior Thesis project and introduction to motion picture industry procedures and practices through interaction with industry representatives. Open to B.F.A. Writing for Screen and Television students only.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTWR 418A
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Writing for Screen and Television

CRS_DESC: Revision of original pilot script, writing of mid-season episode, and completion of bible for original dramatic series developed in first semester.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTWR 419a
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Writing for Screen and Television

CRS_NAME: Senior Thesis in Half-Hour Television Comedy
CRS_DESC: Rewrite, casting, and stage performance of the comedy development process. A rewrite of the final draft and completion of the series bible with multiple seasons.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTWR 420a
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Writing for Screen and Television

CRS_DESC: Writing an episode of an existing dramatic television series within the hour-long format with an emphasis on conception, pitching, characterization and structure.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (CTWR 321 or CTWR 324 or CTWR 505 or CTWR 514A)

CRS_DESC: Examination and creation of the world, characters, and concept for an original hour-long dramatic series. Writing an outline for an original dramatic pilot.
Detailed investigation of specific comedy writers, comedy genres, and the works they've influenced. Lectures include screenings and visiting screenwriters.
Detailed investigation of a specific screenwriter's style and the works they've influenced. Lectures include screenings and visiting screenwriters.
Detailed investigation of various television writers' styles, the worlds they have created, and the works they've influenced. Lectures include screenings and visiting television writers.
Writing an episode of an existing half-hour comedy series, with emphasis on the anatomy of a joke, comedic structure and character.

CRS_NAME: Writing for Film and Television Genres
CRS_DESC: Preparation of proposals and scripts for different types of film or television programming: emphasis on conception, structure, characterization and format.

CRS_NAME: Writing the Original Situation Comedy Pilot
CRS_DESC: Advanced workshop for writing an original half-hour comedy series, including a pilot script, summary of characters, and story lines for first season.

CRS_NAME: Writing the Original Dramatic Series Pilot
CRS_DESC: An advanced workshop in which students create an original dramatic series, including a first script and a summary of characters and story lines. Prerequisite: CTWR-421 or CTWR-434.

CRS_NAME: Rewriting the Original Dramatic Series Pilot
CRS_DESC: An advanced workshop in which an original hour-long television pilot will be rewritten with emphasis on character, world creation and future story lines. Prerequisite(s): CTWR 439. Recommended preparation: CTWR 411.
An advanced workshop in which a feature length screenplay will be rewritten using a specific methodology that focuses on a macro to micro approach to revision.
Examination and analysis of various topics, issues, and resources pertaining to creative, legal, and business perspectives for writers in the entertainment industry.

CRS_NAME: Staff Writing the Sketch Comedy Show
CRS_DESC: Staff writing a sketch comedy show with emphasis on creating comedic characters, political humor, monologue writing, and joke construction. A live show will be produced. Prerequisite: CTWR 404
Staff writing and producing the original episodic drama, from development to post-production.
Strengthening and deepening the ability to conceive and develop ideas that will lead to compelling, authentic, and personally meaningful films. Duplicates credit in CTWR 528.
Introduction to the fundamentals of storytelling with techniques and practices that work best for animated stories.

Dramaturgy for the fiction and nonfiction work. Techniques for creating the original or adapted theatrical length script. b: Development of an outline and feature length, original script. Open to graduate screenwriting (CNTV) and dramatic writing (Theatre) students only.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Writing for Screen and Television, Theatre (Dramatic Writing)

CRS_DESC: Comprehensive re-writing of second and third drafts of a feature screenplay leading to a polished and professional piece.

Critical analysis of the structure of films from the classics to current award winners. Students will learn how to identify key story concepts and break down three act structure in finished films and scripts.

The re-write, casting, and performance stages of television comedy development. The completion of a final draft of the pilot script and series bible. Open only to Writing for Screen and Television master students.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTWR 517a
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Writing for Screen and Television
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student

CRS_DESC: Part B -- writing the series bible and mid-season episode -- is part two of the television thesis course. Students develop their original series further by writing the bible for the series and the mid-season episode which is reflective of storylines, characters and settings developed in part A of the course. Open to M.F.A. Writing for Screen and Television students only.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTWR 519A
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Writing for Screen and Television

CRS_DESC: Intensive workshop oriented specifically to writing and rewriting the most effective and telling dramatic scenes to heighten audience participation and greater story impact.
Investigation of development process for hour-long television, addressing issues of character, world, story and concept. Vetting of multiple series ideas for viability.

Introduction to formal elements of the screenplay through lectures and the workshopping of a complete first draft of a feature-length script. Prerequisite: CTAN 536 or CTWR 505 or CTWR 518. Recommended preparation: CTWR 516.
Emphasizes structural elements crucial to the feature film. Techniques for creating an original or adapted theatrical-length script.
Rewriting the feature-length screenplay. Focus on macro to micro approach to revision.

Development of an original half-hour comedy series; writing of the pilot episode and series bible. Prerequisite: CTWR 514a. Open only to master students in Theatre (Dramatic Writing) and Writing for Screen and Television.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTWR 514a
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Theatre (Dramatic Writing), Writing for Screen and Television
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student

CRS_DESC: Development of an original one hour drama series; writing of the pilot episode and series bible. Prerequisite: CTWR 514a. Open only to master students in Theatre (Dramatic Writing) and Writing for Screen and Television.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: CTWR 514a
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Theatre (Dramatic Writing), Writing for Screen and Television
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student

CRS_DESC: Examination of the links between the brain, creativity, neuroscience and storytelling. Through lectures, screenings, and readings, students will log dreams for use in creative exercises.

CRS_NAME: Advanced Rewriting Workshop in Hour-Long Drama
CRS_DESC: Advanced television writing, emphasizing the rewrite of a first draft pilot script and series bible for an hour-long television series.
Advanced development of the story creation process by examining the core elements of a good story. Compiling a portfolio of story ideas.
Advanced feature screenwriting, emphasizing the rewrite of a first draft script.
Development and pitching of ideas for motion pictures, episodic and television pilots. Reducing ideas to basic components enhancing verbal presentation skills.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (CTWR 305 or CTWR 415B or CTWR 514B or CTWR 533)

CRS_DESC: Development and execution of writing in various genres of film, television, or new media scripts. Prerequisite: CTWR 514b.
An introduction to the expressive range of screen languages in their cultural, historical, and technological contexts.
An in-depth investigation of the close interrelationships among technology, culture and communication to form a solid foundation for digital authoring. Duplicates credit in former IML 101.

CRS_NAME: Media Arts and Practice Studio II
CRS_DESC: Intermediate laboratory exploring computational systems through a series of critical design prompts. Emphasis on digital representation, time-based processes, abstract data and the relationship between humans and computers.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: IML 202
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Media Arts and Practice

CRS_DESC: Development of documentation and archival strategies, with an emphasis on techniques of personal and professional representation.
Emphasizing rigorous multimedia research and authorship strategies, this course prepares students to undertake large-scale digital projects.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (IML 104 or IML 201)
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Investigation of the impact of natural patterns on digital media design. Explores the relationships among chaos, harmony, beauty, proportion, spirituality, holistic systems and shaped experience.
A hands-on mentored research lab experience within the context of media art and in association with a real-world project.
Individual research and readings.
Selected topics in multimedia literacy.

CRS_NAME: The Praxis of Sonic and Visual Media
CRS_DESC: An introduction to digital authorship at the graduate level, with a focus on the potential of multimedia scholarship and networked dissemination.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student, Professional Year 1

CRS_DESC: Deepening skills in audio/video storytelling methods through a semester-long, non-fiction media project.

CRS_DESC: Research leading to the masters degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CRS_DESC: Creation of a work of digital culture, informed by cultural theory, and planned using current design methods and practices. (Duplicates credit in former CNTV 601)

CRS_DESC: Orientation to the profession, opportunities, presentation and analysis of recent developments and applications in Media Arts and Practice. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former CNTV 603)
Introduction to contemporary media theory, with attention to posthumanism, networks, and the post-cinematic, and a demonstration of these concepts in media art.
Introduction to methods of critique, critiques of critique and alternatives to critique, with specific attention to interdisciplinary media-rich practices and works created by students.
Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794a)
Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794b)
Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794c)
Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794d)
Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in CNTV 794z)

CRS_NAME: Writing and Story Art for Vision and Motion
CRS_DESC: Story, narrative structure and storyboarding techniques examined through a creative lens.
The history and practice of media-based installation art, from site-specific architectural projection mapping, to activist and public art, video sculptures and immersive, physical transformations.
Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CRS_NAME: Navigating Media and News in the Digital Age
CRS_DESC: Students will be engaged as discriminating media/news consumers and contributors. Emphasis on critical skills needed to understand, employ, enjoy and help shape our media landscape.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and lab

CRS_NAME: Contours of Change in Media and Communication
CRS_DESC: Provides an introduction to cultivating a curious, critical, and proactive approach to the challenges of social change. Students will be encouraged to develop an expansive and critical definition and understanding of change as it relates to the role of media and communication in producing and responding to political and cultural transformations that shape our status as citizens and our ideas of citizenship.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and one disc

CRS_DESC: Collaborative, cutting-edge, experimental, experiential, interdisciplinary, results-based classes taught in new ways and places. Recommended preparation: ASCJ-220.

Production and distribution of information within large organizations; information networks, organization structure, control and decision-making functions. Resources necessary for effective organizational communication systems.

Roles, responsibilities and requirements of communication functions within corporations; design and implementation of communication plans; strategic message production for internal and external audiences.

Communication consulting skills including facilitation, training,presentation coaching, benefits writing, speech writing, and communication organizational change; consulting basics, proposals, cost estimating, and final reports.
How work settings determine communication: basic structures of communication, influence of technology, social contexts and physical space. Applications to management.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Communication Management

CRS_DESC: Examines images and image manipulation in communication, management and social control. Synthesizes work ranging from cognition and interpersonal behavior to mass media and popular culture.
Theory and research on value and attitude formation and change; consequences for communication and behavior.

Analysis of the innovation dynamics fueled by the information and communication technology revolution; economic, technological, institutional and personal underpinnings of innovation and entrepreneurship

CRS_NAME: Communication Strategies For Innovators and Entrepreneurs
CRS_DESC: Communication research, analysis and strategies for new ventures to establish spread and acceptance in saturated mediascapes. Help founders find persuasive voice and identity.

CRS_NAME: Communication in the Luxury Fashion Industry
CRS_DESC: Examines luxury fashion marketing communication, focusing on connecting with the audience. Topics include history of the industry, media channels, digital platforms and communicating values.
Assess organizations' online needs, to examine the use of the Internet in terms of electronic commerce and global pressures, and design Web page strategies.

CRS_NAME: The Industry, Science and Culture of Video Games
CRS_DESC: History, social dynamics, and cultural impact of video games; developments in technology and design; issues confronting the video game industry and organizations.
Communication strategies for product marketing and advertising; communication's role in developing domestic and international marketplaces; practical applications of persuasion theory.
Use of rhetorical theories and communication models to create organizational identification with internal and external audiences; the role of values and ethics in creating identities.
Cultural and critical analyses of radio and recording industry development and business strategy; influence of legal and regulatory institutions, impact of new forms of distribution.
Explores foundation of U.S. media policy in the digital age; students prepare White Papers on an urgent issue of contemporary digital media and entertainment policy.

CRS_NAME: Hollywood 3.0-Entertainment Industry in the Convergence Age
CRS_DESC: In-depth analysis of the challenges confronting the entertainment industry in the wake of media convergence including a survey of media convergence history and theories.
Focuses on management, production and distribution of scripted film, television and web stories to understand visual storytelling as a communicative strategy for advertising and education.
Applies communication theory and research to understand emerging marketing communication topics and issues.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Communication Management

CRS_DESC: Foundational and advanced practices for copywriting and related design incommunication; integrated analysis of concepts and pragmatics surrounding creativity forcommunication effectiveness

CRS_NAME: Online Marketing Communication Development and Analysis
CRS_DESC: Analysis and development of online communication and marketing campaigns; exploration of current Internet best practices in social media, SEM, privacy, location-based marketing, and online measurement.

Communication strategies in a global marketing environment; analysis of global  local challenges and opportunities; effective global integrated communication to create and sustain competitive advantage
Specialized writing for persuasive and strategic communication contexts. Intensive focus on public relations writing for print, online, broadcast, and social media.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the PR department but may qualify for major credit in CMGT. To register, enroll in PR 562.

CRS_NAME: Methodological Fundamentals of Big Data in Communication
CRS_DESC: Understanding of fundamental methodological issues about big data: types, platforms, tools, analysis techniques, and relevant theoretical frameworks.
How to use effective organizational communication to facilitate crisis prevention, provide leadership during a crisis and manage organizational change.

Evolution, models, metrics and stakeholders. Key communication issues in designing and implementing initiatives, CSR reporting, strategic partnerships and online communities. Analysis of communication paradoxes.
Examination of social scientific theory and research on patterns of media content; effects of mass media exposure on individuals and society; and industry practices.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Communication Management

CRS_DESC: How to communicate through storytelling in contemporary culture. Strategic story development for brands, for self-branding, and for social impact. Story creation utilizes narrative theories and workshop-style participatory activities.
Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the school. Graded CR/NC.
Field experience in applying communication principles to settings in organizations, campaigns, or other contexts; analysis and assessment of issues and problems. Graded CR/NC.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Global Communication, Communication Management, Communication, Digital Social Media, Public Diplomacy (Practitioner and Mid-Career Professional),, Public Diplomacy
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student

CRS_DESC: Social scientific inquiry into human communication; core theories of message production and reception in interpersonal, group and organizational contexts.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Principles and practices of effective oral communication; analysis of the speaking-listening process; selection and organization of speech materials; use of new presentation technologies.
Examines cultural institutions, ideologies, artifacts, and productions; role of culture in everyday life; cultural studies as methodology; culture and power.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Economic and political economic principles for the analysis of communication and media industries including broadcasting, newspapers, motion pictures, music, video games, advertising and public relations.

Theoretical foundation for understanding the construction, consumption, and consequences of entertainment from classical to contemporary times; situates entertainment within the ecology of information and communication.
Experimental and survey methods for communication study; basic statistical concepts, procedures, and tests.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Theories and research in social influence; strategies and tactics of persuasive communications in such settings as politics, public relations, advertising, business.
Analysis of face-to-face interaction; role of communication in the development, maintenance and destruction of relationships; communication processes in managing interpersonal conflict.
Students learn to be consumers rather than creators of social science research. Examines the challenges and opportunities of communicating research through mass media.
Explorations of innovation in the entertainment business. The effects of digital mobile media on TV, movies, music, advertising, social networks and art.
Music as inter-cultural communication and method for exploring race and ethnicity in the constitution of American culture and American self; role of music industry.
Nature and functions of communication in human conflict; development of communication skills for managing conflict productively in interpersonal, organizational and intercultural contexts.

Cultural, social, political, and economic dynamics of communication technologies, including internet architecture, social media, participatory cultures, privacy, surveillance, networked journalism, big data, algorithms, online activism.
Interplay between media and society, including family and children's socialization, inter-group relations and community, pornography and violence, gender and race, media ethics, conduct of politics.
Forms of civic life; opportunities and obstacles in forming, participating in, and disrupting community; issues of knowledge, power, identity; theories/methods of rhetorical analysis and production.

CRS_NAME: The Business and Culture of Celebrity
CRS_DESC: Employs the concept of "celebrity" as an optic through which to view and assess some of the key aspects of the communication revolution.
Survey of mass communication research; history, content, effects, theories, and policy implications of various media.

Group process theories relevant to communicative behavior in small group/team settings, including information exchange, decision making, leadership, and meetings; student team projects testing theoretic propositions.
Social media within the broader social, political, and historical contexts; key themes include labor, Web 2.0, self-branding, celebrity, participation, privacy, online shaming, and activism.

Basic argumentation theory including analysis. Research and evidence, case construction, refutation; discursive and visual argument; diverse fields of advocacy including law, politics, organizations, interpersonal relations.

Cultural variables and social psychological processes that influence intercultural interaction; relationship between communication and culture in diverse settings including business, medicine, and education.
CRS_NOTE: • Diversity: This course satisfies the university's diversity requirement.

CRS_DESC: Cultural implications of computer-mediated communication and related media. Ideological responses to media innovation; debates over artificial intelligence, virtual communities, and virtual reality. Recommended preparation: COMM 339.
Introduction to the medium; history of video games; video games as aesthetic products, cultural products, economic outputs; policy issues, effects, and sites of community.
Advertising as a mode of communication; US advertising history and institutions; economic and policy contexts (domestic and global); critical analysis of advertising texts
Theoretical approaches to the study of media consumption and audiences; examines international media and consumption practices; explores new media's impact on consumption.
Examination of the modern city as a communicative text with London as the case study.
Students engage with a community partner, bridging classroom learning with "real world" experiences by working within the diverse community surrounding USC.
Introduces public diplomacy as a central feature of contemporary international relations and challenges students to locate themselves as both its target and practitioners.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the PUBD department but may qualify for major credit in COMM. To register, enroll in PUBD 369.

CRS_DESC: Exploration of how freedom of speech has been adapted and applied to "new media" from film to computer algorithms and video games.

Oral and written communication skills demanded in the workplace including informative and persuasive speeches; interviewing; team communication; and training material preparation. Recommended preparation: COMM 204
Directed individual research studies of contemporary problems. Supervised laboratory experience. Open only to members of the University debate squad.
Explores social, political and ethical issues in elite sports and how issues are addressed through popular media; examination includes the relationship between sports and politics.

CRS_NAME: Sports, Business and Media in Today's Society
CRS_DESC: An inside look at the important stories, topical issues, trends and historical developments related to the growing influence of business and media on college and professional sports; identifying the key components and meeting the influencers in class that help shape the business side of sports, while recognizing the role the media plays in providing daily coverage across multiple platforms.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the JOUR department but may qualify for major credit in COMM. To register, enroll in JOUR 380.

CRS_DESC: Rhetorical and critical approaches to sports and public discourse; application to sports organizations, the news and popular media; representations of gender and race in sports.
CRS_NOTE: • Diversity: This course satisfies the university's diversity requirement.

CRS_DESC: Popular culture as an indicator of cultural values, a producer and reflection of cultural meaning, and a means of communication; theory and case studies.

How communication processes both create organizations and are constrained by them. Theory and research into topics such as culture, technology, power, leadership and decision-making in a variety of organizational contexts.
Application of critical, sociological and rhetorical theories to sports events and sport media; examination of the role of sports in enacting social change.
Examines case studies on important Italian companies, ranging from the transportation to the luxury goods industries from both an economical and business point of view.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Communication, Journalism, Public Relations

CRS_NAME: Media and Migration in Times of European Crisis
CRS_DESC: Investigates the implications of the perceptual process of mass media generated immigration discourse in Europe.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Communication, Journalism, Public Relations

CRS_DESC: Examination of the modern city as a communicative text with Rome as the case study.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Communication, Journalism, Public Relations

CRS_DESC: Issues of gender in communication, including: mediarepresentations of femininity and masculinity; and gender's rolein communication at the interpersonal, public, and cultural levels.
CRS_NOTE: • Diversity: This course satisfies the university's diversity requirement.

CRS_DESC: Advanced readings in communication theory and research (broadly defined); specialized interest areas of individual faculty on the frontiers of knowledge; seminar topics change each semester.
Provides an overview of 2,000 years of Italian-style communications, from Julius Caesar to Machiavelli, Mussolini and the Mafia.
A foundational understanding of the historic, cultural and theoretical underpinning of the podcast medium with an emphasis on critical listening.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the JOUR department but may qualify for major credit in COMM. To register, enroll in JOUR 412.

CRS_DESC: Gender and news media evolving images of women and men in print and electronic media. Impact of gender in content and style of news, television and cinema. Open to non-majors.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the JOUR department but may qualify for major credit in COMM. To register, enroll in JOUR 467.

CRS_DESC: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduatecredit. Available to juniors and seniors only.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Students gain research experience in the design, implementation, analysis, and reporting of communication research. Students serve as research assistants to faculty members. Not available for graduate credit.

  • Restriction: Registration closed to the following class level(s): Freshmen, Sophomore, Junior

Finding the right grant; how to develop theory, optimize funding, write critial components of grants, form collaborations with experts; how review panels work.

Examination of theoretical models and best practices of academic research and advocacy relationships; students conduct a community-based research project using a model of community-based participatory research.
Explores and analyzes the interaction between culture and economy by observing different types of economic practices.
Explores alternative genres of public-facing writing (blog posts, interviews, op-eds, policy statements, multimedia publishing); considers exemplars of academics engaging with the public.
A supervised course tailored to specific student interests. The professor and student develop a syllabus that permits exploration of advanced or specialized topics. Graded CR/NC.
Independent research designed to demonstrate the student's ability to conceptualize, conduct, and present scholarly research. Parallel to COMM 794. Graded CR/NC.
Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of dissertation. Graded IP/CR/NC.

CRS_NAME: The Power and Responsibility of the Press
CRS_DESC: Explores the role of journalism and social media in society - its influence on government, technology, business, national security, sports, science and entertainment.

Understanding key moments, debates and ideas that have shaped journalism in the United States from the Revolutionary War period through today. Examination of the social, cultural, political and technological aspects of journalism and its impact on the profession and public service.
Field experience in journalism, public relations, or related field.
Report, write and distribute in-depth stories for diverse audiences; enhance understanding of news judgment; develop and maintain sources; engage communities through field reporting.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Journalism

CRS_DESC: Employing a human-centered design framework, students research and develop novel solutions to experience, collaboration and culture issues that pervade newsrooms worldwide.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the ACAD department but may qualify for major credit in JOUR. To register, enroll in ACAD 255.

CRS_DESC: Report, write, produce and distribute in-depth stories produced off beats on multiple platforms for diverse audiences; enhance understanding of news judgment; develop and maintain sources; engage communities through field reporting and emerging digital tools.

  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Journalism

Build a personal website that features a culmination of your previous undergraduate journalism work; craft a professional digital profile using various social media platforms; understand the economics of the news business; prepare to enter the industry.
Emphasis on fundamental skills necessary for photojournalism including camera techniques, story ideas and digital darkroom.

Highlight norms, routines of content, including print, broadcast, video. Focus on opportunities, constraints posed by roles of reporters, fans, players, publicists, agents, leagues, teams.

CRS_NAME: Entertainment, Business and Media in Today's Society
CRS_DESC: An examination of the symbiotic relationship of the entertainment business and the media; press coverage of the entertainment industry; Hollywood's relationship with news media.

Techniques for audio journalism, including effective use of sound, art of the interview, writing for the ear and crafting stories to engage listeners.
A foundational understanding of the historic, cultural and theoretical underpinning of the podcast medium with an emphasis on critical listening.
Production of a well-reported advanced multimedia package, with a blend of text, audio, video, photos, navigation and interactivity; final projects will be published by the Annenberg Media Center.
Techniques of writing the film review; preparation and treatment of form and content; problems, responsibilities and ethics of film reviewing.

A seminar in "how to" interview, research, write -- and place -- professional quality articles for a full range of magazines/newspapers including women's, sports, ethnic, local and national.
News and feature coverage of sporting events, including social and economic factors influencing sports in America.
Techniques of reporting and writing about the entertainment business, economics and finances. Analysis of the skills and background needed for reporters specializing in this area of the news.
Techniques of reporting and writing about the arts, including television, film, theatre, music, graphic arts, architecture and design.
Techniques for covering beats that are the foundation of daily newspaper reporting, including crime, education, immigration and local government.
Tell stories that explore food culture and culinary traditions, become familiar with cultural areas of Los Angeles and become immersed in global food and culture.
Press law; government controls on the news media; legal responsibilities of the journalist.
Gender and news media evolving images of women and men in print and electronic media. Impact of gender in content and style of news, television and cinema. Open to non-majors.

Examine and analyze the ever-changing technology sector of the sports business and sports media worlds. Identify emerging technologies being developed in the sports industry and how they are being utilized to enhance the fan experience.

Fundamental technique studies in a studio setting. Concentration on classical ballet, hip hop and its derivatives, partnering and contemporary techniques essential to the dancers' development. Placement audition required.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Dance

CRS_DESC: Study and guided practice of choreographic repertory. Emphasis in choreographic intention, stylistic approaches and performance technique.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Dance
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Glorya Kaufman School of Dance

CRS_DESC: An introduction to mindfulness and other practices supportive to the dancer explored through reading, viewing, lecture, discussion and cultural contextualization.

An introduction to various genres within Dance and New Media, including simple hands-on work with existing and emerging technologies used in creating and delivering media-dance works. No previous dance experience is required.

Compositional methods and approaches to developing choreographic ideas; integration of improvisational techniques as a means to generate movement ideas and expand movement vocabulary, edit choreographic material, and evaluate and execute choreography and performance.
Creative choreography of theatrical dance for the screen. Emphasis on rhythmic analysis, versatility, composition, notation techniques, and stylizing.

CRS_NAME: Introduction to Dance Forms and Techniques
CRS_DESC: An embodied studio course introducing the foundational techniques, histories and contexts of a variety of dance forms and styles.

African Dance technique at the beginning/intermediate level: knowing, understanding, experiencing culture, emphasizing cultural traditions, community outreach and diversity; works through artistic process, practice, performance, and related activities, using dance, theatre and music work rooted in the African tradition and contemporary African aesthetics; focus on West and Central African traditional dance and music.

An introduction to methods developed from modern and post-modern dance techniques, including the study of the rebellious, individualistic, and democratic nature of dance in the 20th and 21st centuries.

Continued study in the fusion of modern, post-modern dance and classical ballet techniques encompassing the study of the democratic nature of dance and choreographic composition in the 20th and 21st centuries.

An introduction to Classical Ballet technique with beginning-level barre and center work, focusing on correct body alignment and musicality. Development of a basic knowledge of ballet history and terminology.

Continued study of Classical Ballet technique with intermediate-level barre and center work, focusing on developing greater clarity, coordination, musicality, and knowledge of ballet history and terminology.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: DANC 183A
  • Note: If you have previous dance experience, have not completed DANC 183A, and would like to take this course, contact uscdance@usc.edu for a prerequisite waiver or pick one up in KDC 203.

CRS_DESC: Intermediate/advanced study of Classical Ballet technique with emphasis on clarity, precision, musicality, movement quality, and artistic expression. Introduction of beats, tours, advanced adagio and allegro combinations, and optional pointe work.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: DANC 183B
  • Note: If you have previous dance experience, have not completed DANC 183A/B, and would like to take this course, contact uscdance@usc.edu for a prerequisite waiver or pick one up in KDC 203.

CRS_DESC: Advanced/pre-professional study of Classical Ballet, continuing and deepening emphasis on clarity, precision, musicality, movement quality, and artistic expression. Further development of beats, tours, advanced adagio and allegro combinations, and optional pointe work.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: DANC 183C
  • Note: If you have significant dance experience, have not taken DANC 183A/B/C, and would like to take this course, contact uscdance@usc.edu for a prerequisite waiver or pick one up in KDC 203.

CRS_DESC: An introduction to Jazz Dance technique, focusing on African and Latin based diaspora dances with European influences, improvisation, and strength/stretching series.

Continued study of Jazz Dance technique at the intermediate level, focusing on African and Latin based diaspora dances with European influences, improvisation, center work, performance techniques, and strength/stretching series.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: DANC 184A
  • Note: If you have previous dance experience, have not completed DANC 184A, and would like to take this course, contact uscdance@usc.edu for a prerequisite waiver or pick one up in KDC 203.

CRS_DESC: Advanced study of Jazz Dance technique, focusing on Broadway, commercial, and concert Jazz Dance, with a continued emphasis on improvisation, center work, and performance techniques.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: DANC 184B
  • Note: If you have previous dance experience, have not completed DANC 184A/B, and would like to take this course, contact uscdance@usc.edu for a prerequisite waiver or pick one up in KDC 203.

CRS_DESC: An introduction to elements of Hip Hop Dance, including technique, movement, musical rhythm, tempo, and phrasing, as well as the historical context required to develop the skills needed to practice and perform this popular dance form.
Continued study of Hip Hop Dance elements on an intermediate level, augmenting the historical context, technique, fluidity, and musicality required to execute the form with greater movement acuity.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: DANC 185A
  • Note: If you have previous dance experience, have not completed DANC 185A, and would like to take this course, contact uscdance@usc.edu for a prerequisite waiver or pick one up in KDC 203.

CRS_DESC: An introduction to basic and intermediate Bollywood Dance, including technique, movement, musical rhythm, phrases, and choreography. Inspired by the high energy music from Indian films, Bollywood is a fusion form that combines traditional Indian folk and classical dances with Hip Hop, Jazz, Latin, and Middle-eastern dance.

Introduction to International Standard, International Latin, and American Style ballroom dances. Designed to introduce students to the fundamentals of ballroom dance, emphasizing partner connection, communication, and creativity, with the practical application of dance within a social setting.

Continued study in International Standard, International Latin, and American Style ballroom dances. Designed for advanced knowledge in ballroom styles, emphasizing rhythmic sequences, partnering techniques, complex patterns, and performance quality.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: DANC 188A
  • Note: If you have previous dance experience, have not completed DANC 188A, and would like to take this course, contact uscdance@usc.edu for a prerequisite waiver or pick one up in KDC 203.

CRS_DESC: An introduction to basic Tap Dance technique, rhythms, syncopation, and musicality, developing into complex steps and elementary dances with progressive understanding of weight change, improvisation, and combinations of sound.

Continued study of Tap Dance technique, focusing on more complex rhythmic patterns and combinations and introducing advanced steps and combinations, all with continued emphasis on improvisation and musicality.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: DANC 189A
  • Note: If you have previous dance experience, have not completed DANC 189A, and would like to take this course, contact uscdance@usc.edu for a prerequisite waiver or pick one up in KDC 203.

  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Dance
