CRS_DESC: Business technologies. Operating systems. Networks. Application software.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for one lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Web publishing using HTML, CSS and other Web technologies. Concepts and theory of Web site creation, page layout and production. Introduction to advanced topics.
Introduction to Python; intended for students without prior programming experience.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: If you have ANY programming experience, consider ITP 116: Accelerated Programming in Python instead. Visit itp.usc.edu to learn more!

CRS_DESC: Accelerated introduction to Python; intended for students with prior programming experience.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Watch this introduction video bit.ly/uscitp116 for a two minutes overview of the course!

CRS_DESC: Introductory course in computer security. Fundamentals of information security management. Threats to information integrity. Ethical hacking concerns and practice. Policies and Procedures.

Introduction to programming using C++, including variables, operators, conditionals, loops, arrays, vectors, strings, functions, files, structs, pointers, dynamic allocation and an introduction to classes.

Fundamentals of MATLAB: a high-performance numeric computation and visualization environment. Overview of linear algebra and matrix manipulation; using 2-D and 3-D plotting routines; programming in MATLAB; basic numerical analysis.
Survey of game software development through quality assurance and in-depth analysis of the development cycle with a focus on bug testing systems, methodologies and QA Management.
Digital tools for image creation, editing, composition, layout, web page development, professional page layout, and printing with color accuracy.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for one lecture and lab listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_NAME: Introduction to 3D Modeling, Animation, and Visual Effects
CRS_DESC: An applied introduction to the techniques used for modeling, animating, texturing, lighting, rendering, and creating 3D content for games, cinematics, visual effects, animation, and visualizations.
Development of practical Python programming skills through project-based applications; "Pythonic" ways of solving problems in modern computational domains.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (ITP 115 or ITP 116)
  • Note: Watch this introduction video bit.ly/uscitp216 for a two minutes overview of the course!

CRS_DESC: Introduction to data analytics. Basics of databases, applied statistics, data visualization. Leverage data to make critical business decisions.
Explore blockchain technology, a secure and immutable way to record transactions. Learn the workings of cryptocurrencies and explore their impact on financial services, business and contracting.
Concepts and techniques in artificial intelligence; approaches in artificial narrow intelligence; applications of AI that are already changing society; ethical and social questions in AI.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (ITP 115 or ITP 116)
  • Note: If you would like to be added to the waitlist for a section of this course, please fill out the form here: tally.so/r/nPRdrQ This class was formerly ITP 499 "Artificial Intelligence Applications"

CRS_DESC: Modern web development techniques and technologies used to create web applications from ground up. Topics include front-end, back-end, and web servers.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (ITP 265 or CSCI 103)
  • Note: If you would like to be added to the waitlist for a section of this course, please fill out the form here: tally.so/r/nPRdrQ

CRS_DESC: Concepts and technologies used to create database-driven websites. Database design and implementation. Server-side development to connect web applications to databases.

Concepts of computer-aided design in 2-dimensions and 3-dimensions. Creating advanced parts using extrusions, surfaces, and equation driven sketches. Forming assemblies, and sub-assemblies, for motion analysis
Fundamental concepts, techniques, practices, workflows, and tools associated with the practice of user experience and interaction design in web and mobile applications.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Watch this introduction video bit.ly/itp310 for a two minutes overview of the course. If you would like to be added to the waitlist for a section of this course, please fill out the form here: tally.so/r/nPRdrQ

CRS_DESC: The role Information Systems play in an organization. Integration of Business Processes by using Enterprise Resource Planning Systems (ERP).
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Watch this introduction video bit.ly/uscitp320 for a three minutes overview of the course!

CRS_DESC: Ethical Hacking. Penetration Testing. Vulnerability Assessment. Red Teams. Hacker environments, infrastructure, and frameworks. Lateral movement and data exfiltration techniques. Evasion and Anti-Forensics.
Introduction to the Swift programming language, various frameworks, and design patterns needed to develop applications for iOS mobile devices such as iPhones and iPads.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (ITP 265 or CSCI 103)
  • Note: If you would like to be added to the waitlist for a section of this course, please fill out the form here: tally.so/r/nPRdrQ.

CRS_DESC: Character design principles, visual communication and planning for games; polygonal construction, use of image guides and edge flows for realistic deformation.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (ITP 215 or CTAN 452)
  • Note: Watch this introduction video bit.ly/uscitp351 for a two minutes overview of the course!

CRS_DESC: Blockchain technology; transactions without the need for a trusted third-party; and decentralized applications on public blockchains.
Fundamentals of character rigging for video game production and development; optimization of character design, skeleton and mass properties for effective rigging; virtual rigs.
Data structures in C++ including vectors, linked lists, stacks, queues, trees, hash tables, graphs, and parallelism.
Latest advances in blockchain and distributed ledger technologies. Critical analysis of new projects, proposals and protocols. The promise and technical feasibility of use cases.
Cybersecurity project design. Incident response. Teambuilding, management and communications for cybersecurity. Scalable approaches for implementation of Information Security Management Systems.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: ITP 125
  • Note: Watch this introduction video for a great overview of ITP 370 bit.ly/uscitp370!

CRS_DESC: Forensic science techniques. Digital evidence preservation. Processes and methodologies for digital examinations. Cyber crime investigations. Windows file system analysis. Real case scenario analysis and reporting
Underlying concepts and principles required for programming video games (topics include vectors, transformations, 3-D math, geometric primitives, matrices). Prerequisite: CSCI-104 or ITP-365.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (CSCI 104 or ITP 365)
  • Note: If you would like to be added to the waitlist for a section of this course, please fill out the form here: tally.so/r/nPRdrQ.

CRS_DESC: Data models for industry applications. Modeling and designing robust databases. Implementing and querying databases with SQL. Innovations in database applications.
CRS_NOTE:
• Crosslist: This course is offered by the ISE department but may qualify for major credit in ITP. To register, enroll in ISE 382.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Business process integration is the core advantage of using ERP systems. Analyze, configure, and test business processes for a company from the ground up.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: ITP 320
  • Note: Watch this introduction video bit.ly/uscitp422 for a three minutes overview of the course!

CRS_DESC: Applications of advanced concepts in C++ including lambda expressions, templates, secure coding, parallel programming, writing performant code, CMake and continuous integration.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (CSCI 104 or ITP 365)
  • Note: If you would like to be added to the waitlist for a section of this course, please fill out the form here: tally.so/r/nPRdrQ

CRS_DESC: Practical applications of techniques used to develop a programming language compiler.
Use decentralized blockchain technology to propose a use case of trustless peer-to-peer transactions.
Network policy and mechanism, firewalls, malicious code; intrusion detection, prevention, response; cryptographic protocols for privacy; risks of misuse, cost of prevention, and societal issues.
Skills to plan, analyze, build, and launch professional Web sites with actual clients. Includes project management, documentation, technology assessment, security, UI, Q/A, and various methodologies.

Teach students the basic technologies and processes involved in the building web and mobile startups. Students will be introduced to the different aspects of building a web startup including Online Business models, Product management, Agile development processes, Technology platforms and Operations, customer development and online marketing.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: If you would like to be added to the waitlist for a section of this course, please fill out the form here: tally.so/r/nPRdrQ.

CRS_DESC: Independent technology project related to specific topics under the direction of a faculty member.

CRS_NAME: Consultancy Skills for Cyber Security Risk Management
CRS_DESC: Development of consultancy skills; cyber risk assessments; policy evaluations; project team development tailored to business objectives and relevant ISO/NIST standards.

CRS_NAME: Advanced Digital Forensics and Incident Response
CRS_DESC: Advanced Digital Forensics. Cyber Breach Investigations. Incident Response. System Triage. Advanced Windows file system analysis. Trial preparation and testimony.

Technologies, concepts and strategies in the emerging online advertising ecosystem. Strategies and tactics to drive traffic to a website and measure efficacy. Students will work with a real client and budget to craft and execute an online marketing plan.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: If you would like to be added to the waitlist for a section of this course, please fill out the form here: tally.so/r/nPRdrQ.

CRS_DESC: Cyber legal issues, search and seizure, 4th amendment and digital evidence, warrants, private searches, wiretaps, tracking devices, workplace privacy.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Watch this introduction video bit.ly/uscitp479 for a two minutes overview of the course!

CRS_DESC: Practical experience in applying information technology skills in real-world settings. Supervised internship at companies and start-ups. Balancing academic rigor with corporate challenges and deadlines.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration closed to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student

CRS_DESC: Application of mathematics, physics, geometry and programming algorithms in the context of video game programming practice.
Techniques for building the core components of a game engine; 2-D/3-D graphics, collision detection, artificial intelligence algorithms, shading, programming input devices. Prerequisite: ITP-380.
Methodology to store, organize, cleanse, harmonize and stage enterprise data for analytics. Report, visualize, slice and dice, forecast and predict trends.
Examines the design, architecture, and capabilities of in-memory databases and their application to real-time analytics.

A real world, hands-on learning experience on what it's like to actually start a high-tech company. Students will work in teams to design, prototype and implement version 1.0 of a high tech web or mobile startup.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: BAEP 452 and ITP 466 and ITP 476

CRS_DESC: Chemical bonding and structure in crystalline, amorphous and molecular solids; tendency and mechanisms for chemical change; homogeneous and heterogeneous equilibria.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture, one lab and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Mechanical behavior of metals, polymers, ceramics, and composites. Structure-process-property relationships. Mechanical testing, stress-strain relationships, microstructural characteristics and analysis. Material failure (fracture, fatigue, creep) and degradation.

Introduction to polymer physical properties and characterization, relationship to synthesis techniques and processing techniques, natural and synthetic materials, property optimization and modern applications.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the CHE department but may qualify for major credit in MASC. To register, enroll in CHE 475.

CRS_NAME: Introduction to Machine Learning for Materials
CRS_DESC: Introduction to machine learning (ML) for materials applications; basic concepts of machine learning, statistics and probability.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

Atomic electronic states, molecular bonding, crystal structures, diffraction, reciprocal lattice, Brillouin zones, crystal binding, lattice vibrations, specific heat, anharmonic effects, energy bands, metals, conductivity.
Phase equilibria, phase diagrams, diffusion, planar defects, nucleation and growth, spinodal decomposition, phase transformation.

CRS_NAME: Basics of Machine Learning for Materials
CRS_DESC: Introduction to machine learning, basics of python programming and data science tools; hands-on projects of materials and process modeling based on machine learning methods.
Understanding deep learning: for students in engineering, physical and life sciences and computer science with mathematical background.
Behavior of materials under cyclic and static fatigue; plastic instability; life-time predictions; brittle and ductile fracture; crack propagation and plastic blunting.

CRS_NAME: Molecular Dynamics Simulations of Materials and Processes
CRS_DESC: Modeling of materials and processes such as mechanical, thermodynamical, and transport properties using Molecular Dynamics simulation, interatomic potentials including long-range coulomb interactions and quantum corrections.
Materials selection in relationship to design and fabrication, economic considerations, methodology of selection, performance parameters; case studies.

CRS_DESC: Formulation and numerical solution of the equations describing the underground flow of fluids through porous media. Includes mass (contaminant) transport in single and multiphase flow.
Principles of well testing; down hole device; aquifer tests; slug tests; DST; pressure transient modeling in homogeneous and heterogeneous systems; parameter estimation; computer aided techniques.
Understanding deep learning: for students in engineering, physical and life sciences and computer science with mathematical background.

CRS_DESC: Explores broad issues and mitigation measures involved in the analysis and design of complex, uncertain, interacting infrastructure systems needing to be resilient and sustainable.
Integration of engineering problem solving methodologies based on systems concepts. Application to complex, large scale technical systems and problems faced by engineering managers. Case studies.

Probability theory in systems engineering: test design and performance, reliability and maintainability, quantitative decision models. Constraint theory to manage and de-conflict complex requirements. Complexity theory.

Essentials of systems and system-of-systems integration from the perspectives of business, programs, and technology. Process, Legacy, and Systems-of-Systems Integration. Verification and Validation methods. Case studies. Recommended preparation: Bachelor's degree in engineering or physical sciences.
Introduction to systems architecture in aerospace, electrical, computer, and manufacturing systems emphasizing the conceptual and acceptance phases and using heuristics.

CRS_NAME: Systems Architecting and the Political Process
CRS_DESC: Analysis of risks inherent in managing high-tech/high-cost government-funded engineering programs; tools and techniques for coping with the impacts of politically-driven budgets on the engineering design process. Recommended preparation: 2 years of work experience.

Impact of economic factors for systems architects and engineers, tools for understanding these factors, fundamental quantitative analysis of cash flow, life-cost estimating for systems and software engineering.
This project-oriented course elaborates on the process of engaging creative thought, tools and techniques for invention, and issues involved in bringing inventions to the production phase.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the CE department but may qualify for major credit in SAE. To register, enroll in CE 576.

CRS_DESC: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of thesis. Graded IP/CR/NC.
Introduction to the fundamental elements in art making, design creation and thinking, including key principles of process and critical analysis.
Introduction to the fundamental elements in art making, design creation and thinking, including the key principles of process and critical analysis.
An introduction to drawing, both skill and perception oriented, as the basic tool for all the visual arts and design.

Practical introduction to oil and acrylic pigments, painting tools, mediums, processes and contemporary concepts. Primary experience in: color, composition and perception through representational and abstract painting.
Practical and theoretical exploration of the nature of surface, form, volume and mass as fundamental elements of clay sculpture and the ceramic object.
Practical and theoretical introduction to sculpture as dimensional manipulation. Primary exploration of form, mass, gravity, surface, structure and associative recognition in three-dimensional art.
Lecture-studio course on the theory and history behind contemporary art, design, and visual communication; students also create work, informed by ideas from the lecture.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Roski majors are advised not to enroll in this course. This course does not fulfill any requirements for any of the bachelor's degrees offered by Roski.

CRS_DESC: Digital photography as a medium of contemporary art. Includes concept development, DSLR cameras, lighting, digital workflow, software, large format printing and installation.
Studio practice to develop drawing fundamentals for game designers, animators and narrative artists.
Continuation of ART 207a.

CRS_NAME: Black and White Film and Darkroom Photography
CRS_DESC: Introduces film cameras, development, and darkroom techniques, photographic history, theory and practice within an art context.
An introductory course exploring contemporary processes and practices of video experimentation in art including the camera, editing, digital manipulation and spatial and virtual platforms.

Interdisciplinary forum where students develop research skills, learn how to best articulate their artistic production, discuss materials related to their research interests, and critique the work of their peers.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Art, Fine Arts
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Sophomore
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Roski School of Art and Design

CRS_DESC: Directed examination of personal approaches to drawing with emphasis on making visual and artistic decisions and developing additional skills and sources of inspiration. Individual expression will be encouraged.
All aspects of comics will be covered, from writing and composition to inking and marketing through the production of an individual multi-page comic creation.
Illustration techniques and professional practices across the range of fine art, comics, editorial illustration, narrative arts, visual development and others. Digital and hybrid approaches.
Directed examination of historic and contemporary painting concepts and aesthetics, investigation into personal ideas towards the development of a creative visual language and practice in painting.
Directed examination of aesthetic concepts and investigation into personal ideas as they relate to the development of a creative visual language in ceramics.
Directed examination of three-dimensional aesthetic concepts; development of an individual creative vision.
Continued examination of the conceptual, technical, aesthetic and historical tools necessary for a well-informed deliberate art practice. Emphasis on generating self-directed ideas.
A technically and conceptually intensive studio exploring contemporary processes and practices of Internet art and online expression.
An examination of the impact of digital media on contemporary culture, with attention to a particular, changing topic each semester.
Introductory course in various printmaking techniques; necessary skills and inherent expressive qualities of different printmaking methods are explored.
A continuation of ART 280 for third-year students, providing an interdisciplinary forum for artistic practice and a deepening critique of one's work and the work of peers.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: ART 280
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Art, Fine Arts
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Roski School of Art and Design

CRS_DESC: Examination of personal approaches and professional careers in drawing and 2D art making, emphasis on making a body of work with creative freedom in committed studio space.
A studio examination of rotating topics in drawing/painting, either media-based or content-driven, with individual and collaborative projects; topics change each semester.
Independent research of specific topics under the direction of a faculty member. Administrative and faculty approval required.
An experiential/academic opportunity in a museum, gallery, community cultural center or related facility. Lectures, seminars, written analysis and working internship.
Examination of personal approaches and professional careers in painting and 2D art making, emphasis on making a body of work with creative freedom in committed studio space.
Continued directed examination of aesthetic concepts and investigation into personal ideas as they relate to the development of a creative visual language in ceramics.
Individual direction of the study of aesthetic issues in sculpture; investigation of an individual creative vision.
Exploration of the essential skills in woodworking through lecture, demonstration and hands-on training. Includes instruction in joinery and relevant machinery and hand tools.
Introduction to plaster mold making using clay and wax for both ceramics and sculpture. Exploration of various casting materials.
Introduction to metal in fine art. Emphasis on technical proficiencies and effective solutions working in a variety of metals.
In-depth exploration of photographic and artistic concepts as they apply to the articulation of personal work.
An intensive investigation of the mechanics and methodology of contemporary software for video art. Recommended to be taken concurrently with ART 260.
Introduce contextual understanding of performance art history and basic principles of using the body in time and space in relation to an audience in order to convey meaning.
Directed examination of specific printmaking media in relation to personal aesthetic goals and expressive concepts.

A faculty-mentored course supporting advanced conceptual exploration and the development of an ambitious, self-defined series or body of work; may culminate in a group exhibition or individual project.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Art, Fine Arts
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Senior
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Roski School of Art and Design

  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Senior
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Roski School of Art and Design

CRS_DESC: Comprehensive exploration of particular aspects of visual art.
Lecture and discussion course in the professional practice of art featuring formal presentations by visiting artists and scholars. (Duplicates credit in FA 515)
Investigation of creative problems through various media. Course may be repeated. (Duplicates credit in former FA 520)
Provides students with a foundation in the history and theory of studio art and curatorial education and develops their teaching skills in these areas.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the CRIT department but may qualify for major credit in ART. To register, enroll in CRIT 525.

CRS_DESC: Presentation and critique which builds students' skills in presenting and contextualizing their artwork for peer review; analytic discussion regarding directions in contemporary art.
Research leading to graduate degree. Maximum units which may be applied to degree determined by department. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former FA 590)
Credit on acceptance of Thesis. Open only to master students. Graded CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former FA 594a)

  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student

CRS_NAME: Histories of Art, Design and Visual Culture
CRS_DESC: A loosely chronological, thematic survey of art, visual culture, design, and critical theory from the early modern period through modernism (1500 1950).
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_NAME: Critical Theory in Art, Design and Visual Culture
CRS_DESC: An issues-based introduction to critical theory in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries, especially as it relates to philosophy, art, design, and visual culture.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Art, Fine Arts
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Roski School of Art and Design
  • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: This course carries GE credit but it is intended for a specific group of students rather than a general student audience.

CRS_NAME: Global Art, Design and Visual Culture since 1960
CRS_DESC: A critical history of art, design, visual culture, and visual theory since 1960, addressing through a postcolonial/decolonial lens the concepts and practices of "global" art.
CRS_NOTE:

Credit on acceptance of thesis. Recommended preparation: 28 units of coursework. Graded IP/CR/NC. (Duplicates credit in former PAS 594b)

Introduction to the basic elements and processes of visual communication and design. Instruction includes studio projects, lectures and readings. Various media used.
Introduction to the fundamental elements in art making, design creation and thinking, including key principles of process and critical analysis.

CRS_DESC: Exploration of essential elements of traditional and digital design, including color and image-text integration, editing information, typography and sequencing.
Exploration of the processes of germination, ideation and application/execution in design integrated with computer usage.
3D digital modeling, rendering, digital capture and production methods for product, package and environmental design.
Introduction to the study of 3-D Design. Includes a wide investigation of materials, tools, and techniques specific to dimensional design as they apply to package, product, and environmental design.
Advanced exploration of typography and image-text integration, including collaborative projects, pre-press and proofing techniques, narrative concepts and information architecture.
A workshop-based course that focuses on software applications in design and web design.
An intensive studio and lecture course focusing on the applications of graphic design in fashion and related fields.

CRS_DESC: A comprehensive study of visual communication focusing on graphic design from 1900 to the present. An introduction to design thinking, language and principles including political and cultural implications.

CRS_DESC: A continuation of DES 230 to produce finished models and prototypes of package, product and environmentally-based designs in actual and virtual space.

CRS_DESC: Introduction to adult development through the lifespan; biological, psychological, and social processes; gerontology as a career for the future.
Clinical cases for understanding changes occurring with normal aging, health behaviors that modify age-dependent diseases and history, prevention and treatment of age-related diseases and disorders.
Introduction to the brain and mind. A unique multimedia approach to stress how knowledge about the mind is gained from scientific and clinical investigations.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Lecture (1 hr 50min) and Lab (1hr)

CRS_DESC: How psychologists study thinking, memory, emotions, personality, and behavior, and how people change in these throughout adulthood to old age.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: This course carries GE credit but it is intended for a specific group of students rather than a general student audience. Gerontology majors can obtain D-clearance through the department.

CRS_DESC: An introduction to the core curriculum in the study of Gerontology. Research perspectives on adult development and aging; methodological issues; personality and relationship issues; general mental and emotional components of aging; research methods.

CRS_NAME: Policy, Values, and Power in an Aging Society
CRS_DESC: How Americans' political values affect public policy. Studies of landmark legislation to explore the social contract between generations and role of governments in social welfare.
Exploring diversity in the older population and variability in the human aging process.
CRS_NOTE:
• Diversity: This course satisfies the university's diversity requirement.
  • Note: Internet Course

CRS_DESC: Explores nutritional needs and the physiological, psychological, and sociological relationships to nutrition. Laboratory experiments in assessment and evaluation.
Age-related changes in nervous system structure and function; relationship of brain changes to changes in cognitive function and perception; Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases.
Methods of studying, evaluating, and treating cognitive, psychiatric, and behavioral problems associated with medical conditions of old age.
Physiological, psychological, and social health problems of adults as they are impacted by health choices throughout life.
Problems and resources of the middle-aged and older woman in a changing society; including discrimination, stereotypes, employment, social interaction, etc.
CRS_NOTE: • Diversity: This course satisfies the university's diversity requirement.

CRS_NAME: Social and Psychological Aspects of Death and Dying
CRS_DESC: Introduction and critical survey of the current issues, concepts, and research of the social and psychological aspects of death and dying.
Consideration of the biological and social-cultural factors that govern the evolution of life spans and the life of humans and selected animal models. Recommended preparation: statistics

CRS_NAME: Seminar in Molecular and Computational Biology
CRS_DESC: Topical seminar in molecular and computational biology. Junior, senior or graduate standing.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior, Master Student, Doctoral Student
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the BISC department but may qualify for major credit in GERO. To register, enroll in BISC 461.

CRS_DESC: Overview of the concepts, characteristics, skills, and clinical issues of case management in a variety of settings serving older persons.

CRS_DESC: Immersion into lifestyles shown to improve quality of life and extend lifespan by studying populations in "Blue Zone" communities throughout the world.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Maymester: May 15-June 3 (first week on campus, second and third week in Costa Rica).

CRS_DESC: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Supervised experience in one or more community agencies. Graded CR/NC.

CRS_NOTE: • Note: Class is in GER 224 on Tuesdays and GER 116 on Thursdays.

CRS_NAME: Longevity and Death among Ancient and Modern European Populations
CRS_DESC: The discoveries of ancient humans and bodies that have been preserved illuminate the connection between diet, health, and disease.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Maymester: May 15-June 2 (first week on campus, second and third week in Italy).

CRS_DESC: Covers the paradox of emotion in aging, as well as how stress and emotion influence cognition and the brain across the lifespan.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Maymester: May 15-June 3 (first week on-campus, second and third week in Israel).

CRS_DESC: Supervised experience in a geriatric health care setting which allows students to put theories and ideas into practive. Graded CR/NC. Lecture, discussion, and fieldwork.
Examines role of nutrition and genes and the impact each has on longevity and diseases, particularly diseases related to aging.Offered in Genoa, Italy.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Online section only. Does not go to Genoa, Italy.

CRS_DESC: Examination of special topics in the area of gerontology.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Maymester: May 15-June 2 (first week on-campus), weeks 2-3 in South Korea.

CRS_DESC: A web based course analyzing physical, mental, and social age-related changes as well as implications of population aging trends for individuals and society.

CRS_NAME: Marketing and Shifts in Consumer Decision Making
CRS_DESC: Branding, marketing, and consumer behavior through examination of established, transitioning and emerging aging services and organizations.

CRS_NAME: Current Issues in Aging Services Management
CRS_DESC: Basic skills needed for an executive working in an aging services environment. Recommended for entry level administrators and managers.

CRS_NAME: Housing and Community Policies and Programs
CRS_DESC: Examination of the behavioral and social consequences of design and the environment to create a more satisfying physical environment for both frail and active older adults.
Reflections on shifts in preferences for aging in place and the market ramifications of innovations in science and technology on older consumers and service provider.

CRS_NAME: The Mind and Body Connection through the Lifespan
CRS_DESC: An introduction to mind-body processes involved in healthy aging. Examines the interplay of emotions, beliefs, and behaviors in shaping health-relevant biological processes.
Examination of lifespan physiology of human development, growth, and aging; major emphasis in the physiology of the later years and implications for health maintenance.

CRS_NAME: Introduction to Genomic Science for Biologists
CRS_DESC: Broad introduction to genomics for students with a biology background, including overviews of 'wet' genomics techniques, available public databases and useful analytical tools.
Application of nutrition science, physiology, biochemistry, and metabolism to evaluate critically ill patients and plan nutrition intervention and monitoring. Open only to graduate students.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student, Doctoral Student, Graduate Visitor

CRS_DESC: Behavior from adulthood to old age; study of major components of behavior such as perception, cognitive processes, personality, intergenerational relationships, sexuality, and life styles.
Life-span perspective on the sociological theories of marriage and the family, intergenerational relationships, work and retirement, and other forms of social organization.
Major legislation and programs; examination and analysis of policy-making and political processes affecting development and implementation of programs for older persons.

CRS_NAME: Administration and System Management in Programs for Older Adults
CRS_DESC: Application of theories of administration and system management to public and volunteer programs and services for older adults including residential institutions and community programs.
Addresses legal issues and liability arising out of the employer-employee relationship, and how to identify and act proactively to minimize such risk.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student

CRS_DESC: Aging (commonalities and distinctions) as addressed by biologists,psychologists, and sociologists. Topics include researchperspectives, normative agings, functional decline and disability,and aging and society.

CRS_DESC: Introduces medical and health care professionals to the interdisciplinary field of gerontology. Examines the worlds changing demography; effects of aging on physical, psychological and social changes; aging process, ethical issues, aging stereotypes.
Understanding geronpsychology and cognition in advanced age; psychosocial theories of aging and psychodynamic models.
Covers cognitive decline for people with Alzheimers Disease or other forms of dementia. Imaging technology to identify and find treatment options.
Current practices in marketing senior living and associated services. Examines behaviors and preferences of older adults and their families. Explores new media platforms.
Addresses the food services components of senior living. Covers pricing, menu design and nutrition.
Marketing models aimed to provide services for senior living. Analyze various institutions models for marketing, communicating and technological influence to brand a facility.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Class will take place in GER 228A.

CRS_DESC: Students from multiple health professions learn about aging and collaborative team care through a combination of didactic and experiential learning working in a community-based setting.

CRS_NAME: Law and the U.S. Constitution in Global History
CRS_DESC: By examining key constitutional moments involving race, rights, and revolutions, students will explore how legal meaning changes over time.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for Lecture and one Discussion section.

CRS_DESC: Examination of the rules and realities of American politics, and the role politics plays in American life and culture.
Provides a comprehensive analysis of the criminal justice system and an overview of the fundamentals of substantive criminal law.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Watch this video to learn more about the course bit.ly/LAW205 .

CRS_DESC: Analyzes the ethical dilemmas and societal implications of artificial intelligence and debates the future of artificial intelligence regulations and laws.

CRS_NAME: Fundamentals of the U.S. Legal System
CRS_DESC: Introduces the U.S. legal system and its relationship to basic principles of the rule of law. Examines lawmaking institutions, judicial processes and contemporary legal issues.
Examines how American law protects and facilitates intellectual property and its modern utility. Provides a practical understanding of laws regulating patents, copyrights and trademarks.

CRS_NAME: Immigration Law for a New America
CRS_DESC: Examines current immigration law in America, the normative debates over immigration policies and the role the government plays in expanding or limiting immigration rights.
Introduces students to the basic aspects of the legal profession.
Examines topics such as children's suggestibility, decision-making, and risk and resiliency all as they apply to legal settings.
Traces the development of U.S. constitutional and statutory mechanisms designed to fulfill the promise of equality under the law.
The main concepts and topics in American law, in the historical, economic and cultural contexts in which they have developed.
Examines the relevance and application of legal structures to all participants in the sports enterprise by providing an overview of legal and ethical issues.

Examines areas of the law that impact entrepreneurs, starting, operating and financing businesses. Topics include: selection of business entities; securities laws and issues that arise in fundraising; employment law; contracts; torts; intellectual property; global expansion; mergers and acquisitions; and IPOs.
Foundational legal and practice concepts at the intersection of law and psychology through three intersecting systems: the mental health, the criminal and the immigration systems.

CRS_NAME: Individual Rights in U.S. Constitutional Law
CRS_DESC: Explores the U.S. Bill of Rights and the limits that the Constitution imposes on the state majoritys ability to impose its will on an individual.
Individual research and readings.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Freshmen, Junior, Senior, Senior (fifth year), Sophomore

CRS_DESC: Introduces students to the basics of legal writing and research, with a focus on legal scholarship and law review-type journal articles.
Intensive experience with a law-related non-profit organization, or public agency.
Off campus coursework; title of course taken at host institution appears as a section title.
The interpretation and enforcement of promises and agreements.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Gould School of Law

CRS_DESC: The crime problem and the legislative response to it through substantive criminal law; administration of criminal justice through police, prosecutorial, sentencing, and penological discretion.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Gould School of Law

CRS_DESC: Functions of the lawyer in modern society; history and organization of the legal profession; the adversary system; equal access to justice; other problems of ethics and professional responsibility.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Gould School of Law

CRS_DESC: The idea of property as understood through economic and philosophical concepts. Rights in land, water and other natural resources. Forms of shared ownership (e.g., landlord and tenant), and a survey of mechanisms for controlling land use.
Considers the delineation of spheres of responsibility between the judiciary and legislature, the nation and the state, and the government and the individual.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Gould School of Law

CRS_DESC: Examination of the basic sources of law for federal and California jurisdictions, utilizing a vast array of sources from books to computer-assisted research and analyzing research methodology and techniques. Graded CR/D/F.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Gould School of Law

CRS_DESC: Two-semester course focusing on developing analytic and communication skills. Lawyers will analyze legal principles and incisively apply them to facts. Graded CR/D/F.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Gould School of Law

CRS_NAME: Legal Research, Writing, and Advocacy II
CRS_DESC: Continuation of LAW 515. Development of legal research, writing, and advocacy skills. Emphasis on persuasive legal writing, including appellate briefs, and researching statutory and administrative law. Participation in a moot court program. Registration restricted to Law students.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: LAW 515
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Law, Juris Doctor/Communication Management, Law/Economics, Law/International Relations, Law/Philosophy, Juris Doctor/Political Science, Juris Doctor/Religion and Social Ethics, Juris Doctor/Business Administration, Law/Business Taxation, Gerontology/Juris Doctor, Juris Doctor/Public Administration, Juris Doctor/Public Policy, Law/Real Estate Development, Law/Social Work, Juris Doctor/Politics and International Relations, Juris Doctor/Pharmacy

CRS_DESC: The basic structure of government in the U.S., including the constitutionally mandated division of power in the federal government and the federal system of power sharing between state and federal systems. A comparative perspective on selected substantive and procedural matters, such as common law reasoning, jury trials, adversary process, and various aspects of civil procedure. Open to incoming LL.M. students only.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Gould School of Law

CRS_DESC: This course will provide LL.M. and M.C.L. students with a survey of various topics in American law including criminal law, evidence, family law, constitutional law, torts, wills and trusts, administrative law and property law. Open to LL.M. and M.C.L. students only.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Gould School of Law

CRS_DESC: Focuses exclusively on issues related to copyright and fair use, trademark, trade secrets and related laws that seek to protect intellectual property.

  • Diversity: This course satisfies the university's diversity requirement.

CRS_DESC: Introduction to and discussion on clinically relevant topics such as social determinants of health, medical ethics and legal and regulatory aspects, in preparation for experience in the clinical setting.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: This course provides an up close and personal perspective on modern health care delivery in the U.S. A host of facilitators in active medical practice focus on practical knowledge and skills for those planning a career in health care.

CRS_NAME: Introduction to Professionalism and the Practice of Medicine
CRS_DESC: An introduction to professionalism and skills required in the practice of medicine and careers in health care.
Introductions to various health innovations, including pathways, technology, techniques and outcomes. A framework for innovation in healthcare and overview of tools for health innovators.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the ACAD department but may qualify for major credit in MEDS. To register, enroll in ACAD 260.

CRS_NAME: Challenges in the Forefront of Biomedical Ethics
CRS_DESC: Examination of fundamental ethical concepts and principles in clinical health care and biomedical research. Use of film, case studies and discussion. Recommended preparation: MDA-110 or MEDS-220.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: This course will provide an overview of prevalent areas of moral debate in healthcare delivery and biomedical research.

CRS_DESC: Explores the role of medicine/surgery in society, whose ideas about health and disease have undergone enormous changes from antiquity to the present day.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: This course explores the development and role of health care systems in industrialized countries, with a focus on that of the United States. This includes a review of the history of medicine to better understand the current state of health care today and the dilemmas presented.

CRS_NAME: Human Anatomy, Physiology, and the Technology of Medicine
CRS_DESC: Introduction to human anatomy and physiology in relation to common disease processes, and an examination of how technology has transformed western medicine throughout history.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221)
  • Note: Introduction to human anatomy and physiology in relation to common disease processes, and an examination of how techncology has transformed western medicine throughout history.

CRS_DESC: Anatomical structure and function of the major regions of the human body as related to health and disease, using clinical cases, lectures and cadaveric demonstrations.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221)
  • Note: This course is designed to provide comprehensive knowledge of the major regions of the human body through the use of lectures, cadaveric demonstrations, and clinical cases. IMPORTANT NOTE: This course will take place in a hybrid format, with in-person lab sessions at the Health Sciences Campus and other sessions taking place online. Please email mhcs@usc.edu with your USC ID number to request D-Clearance. When the class is full, subsequent requests will be placed on a wait list.

CRS_NAME: The Brain in Health and Disease
CRS_DESC: Study of the human brain through the lens of disease using illustrative case studies, current imaging techniques and potential future treatment for neurological conditions such as Alzheimer's disease.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and (CHEM 103 or CHEM 105A or CHEM 115A)
CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and 1 from (CHEM 103 or CHEM 105A or CHEM 115A)

CRS_DESC: The neurochemistry of psychiatric illness and addiction, introduction to brain and nervous system biochemistry, anatomy and disease states. Covers prescribed medications and drugs of abuse.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and (CHEM 103 or CHEM 105A or CHEM 115A)
CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and 1 from (CHEM 103 or CHEM 105A or CHEM 115A)

CRS_DESC: Overview of the cellular make-up of the human skeleton, the functions of bones, clinical application of this knowledge towards bone-related diseases, and introduction to technological advances in orthopedic surgery.
An examination of frequently treated diseases with the greatest impact on society. Involvement of medical specialists as guests.

An examination of the health care system of the United States, from the perspective of the physician and other health professions. Particularly covers health care systems as a workplace and how medical professionals fit into and operate within it.
Basic medical and developmental concepts that are important during the infant, child and adolescent phases of life, as well as guest lectures from health care professionals in the pediatric field.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: MEDS 220
  • Note: The objective of this course is to introduce students to the core principles relating to the care of the infant, child, and adolescent patient. Students will be exposed to the main issues pediatricians face in modern health care delivery to patients aged 0-18 years. They will also gain knowledge about the various career options in the field of Pediatric Medicine. Departmental clearance required to register for this course. Please contact Eli Chau at mhcs@usc.edu to request D-Clearance.

CRS_DESC: Emphasizes the team-based approach used by forensic scientists, medical examiners and coroners to investigate the circumstances and determine the cause/manner of death. Prerequisites: BISC 220 or BISC 221 and MEDS 220. Open only to sophomores, juniors, and seniors.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and MEDS 220
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Sophomore, Junior, Senior, Senior (fifth year)
  • Note: Dr. Lakshmanan Sathyavagiswaran is the former Chief Medical Examiner-Coroner for Los Angeles County. Learn about high profile cases such as O.J. Simpson, Dean Carter, Phil Spector and Michael Jackson. investigate the circumstances and determine the cause and manner of death of decedents falling under the jurisdiction of the coroner.

CRS_DESC: Introduction to the spectrum of surgical care, taught by surgeons, with the goal of developing an appreciation of the role that surgery plays in society. Prerequisites: BISC 220 or BISC 221 and CHEM 103 or CHEM 105a or CHEM 115a and MEDS 220. Open only to juniors and seniors.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and (CHEM 103 or CHEM 105a or CHEM 115a) and MEDS 220
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and 1 from (CHEM 103 or CHEM 105a or CHEM 115a) and MEDS 220
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: The basic aspects of cancer biology, prevention, diagnosis and therapy, as well as guest lectures by oncology researchers and health professionals.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221)
  • Note: Course includes off-campus travel for clinical activities (see syllabus for further information).

CRS_DESC: An introduction to the practical realities of modern obstetric and gynecology practice from the point of view of practicing surgeon scientists at USC. Prerequisites: BISC-220 or BISC-221 and MEDS-220.
Introduction to integrative health care; a holistic approach to medicine combining conventional medical therapies with evidence-informed complementary alternative medicine.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Introduction to Integrative Health Care; a holistic approach to medicine combining conventional medical therapies with evidence-informed complementary alternative medicine.

CRS_DESC: Principles of emergency medical services, ranging from pre-hospital care and advanced life-saving, to minor injuries and illnesses. Interactive experience with ER physicians/emergency health care providers. Prerequisites: BISC 220 or BISC 221 and MEDS 220. Recommended preparation: MEDS 260.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and MEDS 220
  • Note: Course is taught by practicing Emergency Medicine physicians, and offers hands-on activities at LAC+USC Medical Center Simulation Training Center. Most class periods held at UPC, some class periods held at LAC+USC Medical Center.

CRS_DESC: Medical physiology principles of people under "extreme" wilderness conditions, factors affecting remote medical care, and basic survival strategies, led by Emergency Medicine physicians. Prerequisites: BISC 220 or BISC 221 and MEDS 220.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and MEDS 220
  • Note: Course is taught by Emergency Medicine/Wilderness Survival physicans. Course includes off-campus field trips (see syllabus for further details).

CRS_DESC: Individual research and readings. Recommended preparation: MEDS 300 and MEDS 360. Not available for graduate credit.Prerequisite: BISC 220 or BISC 221) and CHEM 103 or CHEM 105a or CHEM115a.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and (CHEM 103 or CHEM 105a or CHEM 115a)
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and 1 from (CHEM 103 or CHEM 105a or CHEM 115a)
  • Note: The HSC Track provides students with a unique opportunity to conduct research with USC faculty mentors who are amongst the top researcher in their respective fields. The CHLA Track is designed to provide exposure to clinical research projects and direct patient contact in the CHLA Emergency Medicine Department. Please contact Elizabeth Chau at mhcs@usc.edu for D-Clearance.

CRS_DESC: Explores the social determinants of health through supervised on-site practicum with the Community Health Advocates Team at Childrens Hospital Los Angeles and didactic sessions.

Exploration of biological and epidemiological fundamentals of tuberculosis including dynamics of transmission among populations. Overview of clinical manifestations, diagnosis, and treatment of infections.

CRS_NAME: Global Health Modules, Maternal and Child Health
CRS_DESC: Biopsychosocial, cultural and economic aspects of womens health: pregnancy, childbirth, marriage. Examination of health promotion and policy efforts to improve womens health globally.

Focuses on children in emergency situations, including natural and man-made disasters, such as floods, earthquakes, conflicts, or war, with an emphasis on the poorest and most vulnerable children. Open only to Global Medicine majors.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Global Medicine

CRS_NAME: Medical Spanish for the Health Professions
CRS_DESC: Spanish language course for students planning to enter the health professions. Graded CR/NC.
Exploration of the threat of major worldwide epidemics and diseases with a focus on the recent emergence of new plagues.

CRS_NAME: Global Health Modules, Sexually Transmitted Infections
CRS_DESC: Examines clinically relevant perspectives from distinguished international authors on STI issues and the devastating effect on particular geographical regions around the world.
The basics of human anatomy (gross anatomy, histology, radiographic anatomy), physiology (cellular physiology, organ system areas) and pathology (general, systemic, cellular pathology).

CRS_NAME: Clinical Medicine and Healthcare Delivery in Panama
CRS_DESC: A two-week course providing students with hands-on experience in the practice of rural medicine as they gain exposure to the various socio-economic factors present in Bocas del Toro, Panama. Recommended preparation: MEDS 500, MEDS 501, MEDS 510, MEDS 511, MEDS 514, MEDS 515. Open only to Global Medicine majors.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Global Medicine

CRS_NAME: Global Health Field Study, New York
CRS_DESC: Two-week course providing students with a solid understanding of the United Nations major agencies influential in global health, their mandate, their strengths and challenges. Includes field visit to selected UN organizations all located in NYC. Open only to Global Medicine majors.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Global Medicine

CRS_DESC: A systematic survey of basic and clinical nutrition that provides an overview of critical public health-nutrition issues in both the developing world and industrial society.
Exploration of the provision of palliative care and analysis of factors affecting the increased burden of palliative care provision facing developing regions of the world.

Examination of typical composition and function of interprofessional healthcare teams. Exploration of roles of team members and purview of care issues and common challenges, including medication management, inpatient/outpatient decision making, and care plan implementation.

CRS_NAME: SARS-CoV-2 Outbreak in the United Kingdom
CRS_DESC: Critical examination of the SARS-CoV-2 Outbreak in the United Kingdom including the geographic spread of the disease, pathology of respiratory illness and evaluation of the delivery of acute and primary health care in the context of the U.K.'s public health infrastructure.
Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
Internship course on the use of new technology based on sensors and wireless communications to the healthcare industry.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Electrical Engineering (Wireless Health Technology)

CRS_DESC: Internship course on the use of new technology based on sensors and wireless communications to the healthcare industry. Continues material from GM-597a. Open only to M.S., Electrical Engineering (Wireless Health Technology) students. Graded CR/NC.
Overview of microbes, their life cycles and the host responses they elicit, evade or exploit, including the manipulation and the malfunction of the immune system.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the INTD department but may qualify for major credit in MICB. To register, enroll in INTD 522.

CRS_DESC: Virus structure and chemistry; virus-cell interactions; aspects of virus genetics; molecular biology; pathogenesis, immunology, and evolution of viral infections.
Intensive examination of selected topics in microbiology. Student presentations and critiques. Required of all graduate students.
Critical discussion of current research topics. Students present published and unpublished research results for discussion and critique.

Mammalian organ systems operation during health, and pathophysiologic analysis of related diseases with focus on neuroscience, immunology, metabolism, endocrine, reproduction, GI and liver. Faculty from basic and clinical sciences.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the INTD department but may qualify for major credit in MICB. To register, enroll in INTD 573.

CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student

CRS_DESC: Examine experimental design approaches for experimental and clinical neuroimaging investigation. Topics on how to develop rigorous experiments to test theories of cognitive and clinical neuroscience.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Neuroimaging and Informatics

CRS_DESC: Addresses the current neuroinformatics approaches to large-scale data representations, mining, and visualization in brain imaging. Open only to Neuroimaging and Informatics majors.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Neuroimaging and Informatics

CRS_NAME: Brain Architecture and Neuroanatomic Exploratory Techniques
CRS_DESC: Introduction to basic theories and methodological approaches to neuroanatomy in animal models including histology, microscopy, behavioral investigations, and neuroinformatics.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Neuroimaging and Informatics

CRS_DESC: Lectures on human genetics and epigenetics. Discuss how applying these concepts to brain imaging advances our understanding of healthy development and neurological disease. Emphasis on critical thinking applied both to designing neuroimaging genetics studies and to constructively assessing peer work and existing neuroimaging genetics literature.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Neuroimaging and Informatics

CRS_NAME: Introduction to Data Science in Neuroimaging
CRS_DESC: Basics of data science as applied to neuroimaging data. Topics include neuroimaging data preparation and quality control, basics of programming and statistical models and machine learning techniques appropriate for the analyses of neuroimaging data.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Neuroimaging and Informatics

CRS_DESC: Learn writing and communication elements critical for success in science-related fields, including clear writing, effective presentations and career development skills.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Neuroimaging and Informatics

CRS_NAME: The Practice of Educational Speech-Language Pathology
CRS_DESC: Examination of the interprofessional practice of educational speech-language pathologists and the multiple professionals working in the pediatric arena to serve children in schools.
Exploration of how our understanding of hearing and balance disorders continues to evolve with advances in science and technology, with opportunities for interprofessional practice and collaboration.
Introduction to the discipline and practice of audiology, including the nature of hearing and balance, how these systems are clinically assessed and impacts of altered function.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Speech-Language Pathology
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Keck School of Medicine

CRS_NAME: Autism Spectrum Disorder, AAC and Cognitive Communication Di
CRS_DESC: Assessment and treatment of Autism Spectrum Disorders and other cognitive disabilities including language, social skills, behavior, consideration for assistive technology and augmentative and alternative communication.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Speech-Language Pathology
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Keck School of Medicine

CRS_DESC: Nature of normal voice production and the assessment and treatment of physiological and other disorders of pitch, loudness, voice quality, including resonance and alaryngeal voice.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Speech-Language Pathology
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Keck School of Medicine

CRS_DESC: Principles, methods and materials to assess communication disorders. Models of assessment and testing, techniques, administration, scoring and interpretation, report writing and related issues.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Speech-Language Pathology
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Keck School of Medicine

CRS_DESC: Anatomy and physiology of the normal swallow and neurological/oncologic disorders which affect the swallowing process. Current practice for clinical and instrumentation analysis, evaluation and treatment.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Speech-Language Pathology
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Keck School of Medicine

CRS_DESC: Supervised clinical hours in assessment and treatment of individuals with varying communication disorders at a variety of age levels in educational or medical settings.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Speech-Language Pathology
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Keck School of Medicine

CRS_NAME: Research/Capstone in Communication Sciences and Disorders
CRS_DESC: Capstone Research Project addressing a problem in the field of communication sciences and disorders. Students will work with a PhD-level faculty member and will culminate in a submission for presentation in a poster session at a professional conference.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Speech-Language Pathology
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Keck School of Medicine

CRS_DESC: Speech-language pathology clinical experience in a supervised school-based, medically-based or private practice setting.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Speech-Language Pathology
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Keck School of Medicine

CRS_DESC: Professional issues that affect speech-language pathology in different work settings. Practice issues, licensing and certification, ethics, reimbursement and funding, national and state practice guidelines.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Speech-Language Pathology
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Keck School of Medicine

CRS_DESC: Topics related to assessment and treatment of fluency disorders. Theories, characteristics and behavioral and psychological and psycho-social impact. Clinical focus, counseling and transitional planning.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Speech-Language Pathology
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Keck School of Medicine

CRS_DESC: Explores the societal issues related to pain, including the role of culture, ethnicity, caregiving, social and psychological factors related to pain and pain management.
Evaluation of patients suffering from pain, distinguishing between types of pain that may be acute or chronic.
Anatomical survey of the human musculoskeletal system, focused on common pathologies that generate pain.
Anatomy of peripheral and central nociceptors, molecular mechanisms that underlie primary responses, neural networks, and neural mechanisms involved in hyperalgesia and allodynia.
Collaborative research project or supervised internship (practicum) incorporating a service learning approach.
Collaborative research project or supervised internship (practicum) incorporating a service learning approach.
Collaborative research project or supervised internship (practicum) incorporating a service learning approach.
Multiple elements including weekly online discussions of cases; learning need assignments; defense of an 18 cases or scenarios e-Portfolio.
Multiple elements including weekly online discussions of cases; learning need assignments; defense of an 18 cases or scenarios e-Portfolio.
Multiple elements including weekly online discussions of cases; learning need assignments; defense of an 18 cases or scenarios e-Portfolio.
Public Policy and Legal Issues in Pain Medicine including the California Medical Board Guidelines for Pain Medication, CURES, and legislation related with the discipline.
Trace through history our collective understanding of pain by examining the people, theories, and technologies which have brought us to our modern understanding.
Focus on pain caused by nervous system dysfunction; assessment, physiology, diagnoses and treatment.
Information and demonstration on specific psychological treatments to decrease pain levels and manage pain flares.
Physical and Occupational Therapy techniques to assess and treat chronic pain.
Patients who suffer from chronic pain often fail to respond to basic treatments. Therefore it is crucial for clinicians to be familiar with different treatment options.
Foundational knowledge of orofacial neurogenic pain and headache disorders; prevalence, differential diagnosis, prevention and management.

Relationship between histopathological and clinical manifestations of disease and their underlying molecular mechanisms. Topics include inflammatory, developmental, environmental, degenerative, and neoplastic disease processes.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: INTD 550
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the INTD department but may qualify for major credit in PATH. To register, enroll in INTD 551.

CRS_NAME: Emerging Trends and Methods in Molecular Pathology
CRS_DESC: Discuss emergent methodologies in molecular pathology with emphasis on applications important for genetics and epigenetics changes in various diseases, Sequencing Technologies, Data Analysis, Forensic Pathology.

Mammalian organ systems operation during health, and pathophysiologic analysis of related diseases with focus on neuroscience, immunology, metabolism, endocrine, reproduction, GI and liver. Faculty from basic and clinical sciences.

CRS_DESC: Lectures and student presentations on advanced topics in molecular, cellular and systemic physiology. Open to Systems Biology and Disease, Physiology and Biophysics, and Pathobiology students only. Graded CR/NC.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Pathobiology, Physiology and Biophysics, Integrative Biology of Disease

CRS_NAME: Foundations in Health Education and Promotion
CRS_DESC: Overview and application of behavioral theories to the field of health education and promotion. Examines the determinants of health behavior and strategies for change at the individual, group and community level.
Introduction to the application of strategies and tools for practice in public health, including policy advocacy, leadership and management, program planning and evaluation, health communication.
Examines quality assessment at different levels of the health care system including health plans, physicians, hospital and integrated system performance.

CRS_NAME: Health Service Delivery in the U.S.
CRS_DESC: Historical development of the American health care system; determinants of health care utilization; role of health care providers; health policy; public health services; and health care finance.

Concepts of biostatistics; appropriate uses and common misuses of health statistics; practice in the application of statistical procedures; introduction to statistical software including EXCEL, SPSS, nQuery. Laboratory.
Major parametric and non-parametric statistical tools used in biomedical research, computer packages including SAS. Includes laboratory. Lecture, 2 hours; laboratory, 2 hours.
Statistical methods for analysis of categorical data including dichotomous, ordinal, multinomial and count data, using Stata package. Includes laboratory.

Terminology/uses of epidemiology and demography; sources/uses of population data; types of epidemiologic studies; risk assessment; common sources of bias in population studies; principles of screening. Recommended preparation: algebra
Statistical methods for analysis of various experimental designs. Parametric analysis of variance (ANOVA), repeated measures methods, crossover designs, non-parametric ANOVA.

CRS_NAME: Multivariate Statistics in Health Behavior Research
CRS_DESC: Advanced training in multivariate statistical techniques involving general linear modeling, mixed modeling and basic latent variables analysis in health behavior research
Overview of epidemiologic research in cancer. Selected cancer sites will be covered to highlight study design and conduct, exposure assessment, data analysis and interpretation.

CRS_NAME: Statistical Methods for Epidemiological Studies I, II
CRS_DESC: Principles and methods used in epidemiology for comparing disease frequencies between groups. Restricted to the analysis of binary outcome variables.

CRS_NAME: Moving Toward Health Equity in the United States
CRS_DESC: A thoughtful perspective on U.S. health services delivery while introducing students to social inequalities in health.
Techniques for the solution of statistical problems throughout intensive computing; iterative techniques, randomization tests, the bootstrap, Monte Carlo methods. Lecture and required laboratory.

CRS_NAME: Pre-Departure Training to Optimize Global Health Experiences
CRS_DESC: A comprehensive pre-departure training course intended to enhance the learning experience for all KSOM learners participating in global health (STEGHs).
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following school(s): Keck School of Medicine

CRS_NAME: Introduction to the Theory of Statistics
CRS_DESC: b: Theory of estimation and testing, inference, analysis of variance, theory of regression. Recommended preparation: college-level calculus and linear algebra.
Design, conduct, and interpretation of results of clinical trials; emphasis on principles affecting structure, size, duration of a trial, and the impact of ethical and practical considerations.

International variations in health status with a focus on the impact of socioeconomic status, politics, environment, education and gender in etiology of illness, access to health care, progression of disease, and recovery.

Application of communication theories and methods to community health problems. Includes background assessment, program design, evaluation, social marketing, media advocacy, review of major health campaigns.
Survey of natural history of infectious disease, methods of disease control and outbreak investigation, and an overview of the epidemiology of injury. Prerequisite: PM-512.

Core concepts, methods and values of public health program planning and evaluation, including community needs assessment, writing objectives, designing health promotion programs, process and outcome evaluation.

Genetic principles; design and analysis of family studies; introduction to likelihood estimation; segregation and linkage analysis; biomarkers of exposure, susceptibility, and disease; laboratory methods; susceptibility genes; association and linkage disequilibrium.
Theory, methods and procedures of network analysis with emphasis on applications to public health programs.
Transfer function models; stationary, nonstationary processes; moving average, autoregressive models; spectral analysis; estimation of mean, autocorrelation, spectrum; seasonal time series.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the MATH department but may qualify for major credit in PM. To register, enroll in MATH 545.

CRS_DESC: Examination of major policy issues in the U.S. health care delivery system to understand policy options in reforming health care and reducing health care disparities.
Principles of genetics and genomics as they apply to the study of the molecular basis of human diseases.
Explores the fundamental concepts of cancer epidemiology, including the molecular basis, descriptive epidemiology, and historical and groundbreaking studies that have impacted the field.

CRS_NAME: Intervention Approaches for Health Promotion and Disease Prevention
CRS_DESC: Approaches for modifying health behavior in varioius settings and within diverse populations. Emphasis on practical considerations necessary to design and implement interventions with demonstrated effectiveness.

Current public health issues and research topics relating to 21st century challenges and threats. Lessons learned and best practices to strengthen public health systems and enhance public health readiness and preparedness.
An introductory course in the statistical methods used in the analysis of human genetic data.

Mammalian organ systems operation during health, and pathophysiologic analysis of related diseases with focus on neuroscience, immunology, metabolism, endocrine, reproduction, GI and liver. Faculty from basic and clinical sciences.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the INTD department but may qualify for major credit in PM. To register, enroll in INTD 573.

CRS_DESC: Study designs, exposure time response, longitudinal, spatial, ecologic correlation and mechanistic models, measurement error interactions, measurement error, public policy implications.
Introduction to the core concepts and methods of planning and implementing health-related programs and research in resource-constrained settings.

CRS_NAME: Global Health, Law and Human Rights
CRS_DESC: Highlights the complex interactions between global health, law and human rights, emphasizing the use of human rights in public health thinking and practice.

CRS_NAME: Qualitative Research Methods in Public Health
CRS_DESC: Introduction to common uses of qualitative research methods in public health research and application. Methods include ethnography, participant observation, open-ended interviewing, and focus groups.
Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CRS_DESC: Introduces Masters and Ph.D. students in the Health Sciences to Machine Learning methods and their Biomedical applications.
